editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p: I Have very ≈øadly ob≈øerved the great di≈øtre≈øs of Humane Affairs, through mi≈øcarriages every way in point of Religion.

For while the Powers of this world and Eccle≈øia≈øtick Juri≈ødictions take it for their Right, to impo≈øe by ≈øevere Penalties, and dreadful Cen≈øures, what they think fit under ≈øo great a name; they yet neither can a≈ø≈øure any one, they are not, or do not u≈øe to be mi≈øtaken in their recommendations; or that all their Authority or Power ≈øhall excu≈øe and acquit tho≈øe that obey them, when they appear before Gods Tribunal; ≈øo that it is impo≈ø≈øible the Judgment or Con≈øcience ≈øhould have any repo≈øe here.

On the other ≈øide, ≈øome not only out of Recoyl for ≈øelf-pre≈øervation, or out of de≈øign, but from Furious Wild Principles, have broken out into publick di≈øturbance, to make room for what they have proclaim'd, as the Kingdom of God and Chri≈øt, to the great ≈øcandal of True Religion, the imbrewing their hands very horridly in Blood, and the ≈øeeming Ju≈øtification of utmo≈øt Rigors, again≈øt
any pretences of Religion, except according to Law.
Be≈øides all this, private Feuds and Animo≈øities, vehement and angry di≈øputes, are every where clamorous, and people hereupon in great Amu≈øe, what they ≈øhould believe or do.
Now ≈øince there is no doubt, all the≈øe evils are fore≈øeen by God; there is as little doubt, that there are ≈øure Remedies provided again≈øt them.
I have then upon the whole this account to give the Reader.

That the ob≈øervation of ≈øo many Counter-Cries of Opinion, ≈øuch great Exa≈øperations in mens Affections, ≈øuch Complaints of oppre≈ø≈øion of Con≈øcience by undue Laws, ≈øuch Recriminations of Faction, Sedition, Fanatici≈øm, not only among Chri≈øtians, but among Prote≈øtant Chri≈øtians, and of the ≈øame Common National Intere≈øt, mov'd me to ≈øeek Retirement to ≈øome Rock of Certainty, that I might be at perfect Peace upon, in full ≈øatisfaction of Judgment and compo≈øure of Affection: and having found Natural Religion as certain as our Faculties, and Fundamental Chri≈øtianity, in mo≈øt things of the ≈øame immediate certainty as Natural; in all things after due exploration, of the ≈øame final certainty, I am ≈øo far at Peace in my Judgment, as to have no doubt WHAT IS TR∆≤TH in relation to Eternal Happine≈øs, if ten thou≈øand more of Opinions
encompa≈ø≈øed me round about; ≈øo far at Peace in my Affections, as not to be in Commotion with any man that gives Te≈øtimony to Chri≈øtian Charity, that he is a ≈øtrict ob≈øerver of Natural Religion, and Fundamental Chri≈øtianity; one E≈ø≈øential Rule of both which is, Love, Peace and Mercy to all that are centred in this Natural Chri≈øtian Religion, though they may adjoyn or refu≈øe ≈øome Eccentrick Placits that do not harm the Foundation.

La≈øtly, I am a≈ø≈øur'd this very Natural Religion e≈øpou≈øed by Chri≈øtianity, well con≈øidered and ob≈øerved, would di≈øarm the world of tho≈øe In≈øtruments of Cruelty in the Cau≈øe of Religion, ≈øo extreamly abhored by it; whether u≈øed by angry ≈øupreme Powers, or unju≈øtly taken up by Seditious, Ambitious or Fanatick Subjects. Which Cruelty men are ≈øain to borrow from wild Bea≈øts, no ≈øuch being given by the Gracious Author of all things to ≈øo excellent a Nature as he made the Humane, and therefore mo≈øt certainly not by the Redeemer, nor his Religion, who came to fill the world with Innocency, Goodne≈øs and Peace, after ≈øo great an Inva≈øion of Barbarity and Cruelty.

Now having found this ≈øatisfaction my ≈øelf, I make offer of it, if it may be the ≈øame to others, asking only Candid Interpretation in particular management, the main Principle being above the need of pardon or the Fear of Indignation.

Although the Di≈øcour≈øe (being intended much ≈øhorter) is not di≈øtingui≈øhed in the Body of it into Chapters or otherwi≈øe; yet that the Reader may have a guidance into the main De≈øigns of it, I have prefixed this Summary of Heads of Di≈øcour≈øe following each other.

our ≈øelves from that Body we are of: But that All our Things 1 Cor. 16. 14. may be done in Charity.

Rule. 9. In the la≈øt place, let us not think, Nations and other Incorporations of mankind ≈ølide away with this world, and are wholly lo≈øt in the future ≈øtate of Things; and that only every man ≈øhall appear, and be judg'd ≈øingly by him≈øelf: Our Re≈øurrection, which is the day of our Regeneration, of our new life, and appearance in Bodies, will pre≈øent us not only ≈øingle, but in our ≈øtate of Community, wherein we were here in the world; even from Families to Nations, that we may receive the things done in tho≈øe Bodies, as well as in our own Bodies; then the Good we have done, or omitted to do; and the Evil we have with≈øtood, or been the occa≈øion of, or not prevented, when we might, ≈øhall be ≈øeverely accounted for by each in their ≈øtation.

Each Magi≈øtrate ≈øhall be ≈øurrounded with his ≈øphere of Authority, wherein he was ≈øet here, and judg'd in that: And each Mini≈øter of Religion ju≈øtified or condemned in that very Orb, wherein he was fix'd as a Star. And the ≈øeveral Magnitudes of both Magi≈øtrates and Mini≈øters will then be dreadful to them; however they have coveted, and been Ambitious of them here, if they have not inlightned their whole ≈øpace, becau≈øe their Judgment will be greater. Even every man ≈øhall be judg'd by his Services to the Publick in his place and ≈øtation, how private ≈øoever, if it hath never ≈øo little exceeded his ≈øingle capacity. And who in his Rea≈øon can think? God will then account with men for Mint and Cummin, ≈ømall and di≈øputable Things, how≈øoever zealous, or rather fond of them they have been in them≈øelves, and earne≈øt with others concerning them: Tho≈øe things that have truly center'd in the Glory of God, and the Salvation of mens ≈øouls, in Faith, Repentance, and a Holy Life, in Love and Peace will be of the only moment at that Tribunal.

This therefore ≈øhould be the mo≈øt powerful per≈øwa≈øive upon us, to do all the good herein we can, in that Community wherein we are fix'd, according to our Talent, though but a ≈øingle one (much more if our Talents have been Two or Five), that we may in that Day of Recompences enter into the joy of our Lord.
THE Woe of Scandal: OR, SCANDAL In its General NATURE and EFFECTS;

Now for the ≈øtrengthening ≈øome parts of this di≈øcour≈øe by Con≈øiderations that have arrived to my Thoughts, ≈øince I had ≈øet an end to the Treati≈øe it ≈øelf; they have ari≈øen from the clo≈øe ob≈øervation of the Contexture of the Lord's Sermon upon Scandal, as it is Recorded e≈øpecially in this 18th of Matthew, and Mark 9. and Luke 17. Compared with the Debates of the Apo≈øtle to the Romans, and the Corinths, which are the mo≈øt eminent Seats of the Doctrin of Scandal, we have in all the Scripture.

Our Saviour therefore, who≈øe chief bu≈øine≈øs into the World, was his recovery of it from Scandal, the Deception, and the Ruin of it, by giving ≈øatisfaction to the Divine Glory, for the di≈øhonour done to it by Scandal, hath ble≈ø≈øed us with as Soveraign Arguments and In≈øtructions again≈øt either giving or receiving it.

But y ‚Ä¢ t, that they have a particular poignancy again≈øt Scandals within his Church, and one more particular kind, given by a particular ≈øort of Men, and directed again≈øt another particular ≈øort of Men, will be mo≈øt evident from the ≈øurvey I am now to give of his Heaven-born Di≈øcour≈øe.

The occa≈øion of it was the Di≈øciples coming ≈øolemnly to him with a grand Quere, in which no doubt their Ambition, a very ignorant Ambition, was deeply concerned. Now though this being Converted, and becoming as little Children, be very profitably, and pertinently applyed to Regeneration; yet, con≈øidering it in the Scope, and whole Context, it is very evidently de≈øigned to that Humility, Unimperiou≈øne≈øs, ≈øen≈øe of the danger of peri≈øhing for ever; Innocency, and Inoffen≈øivene≈øs from Scandal, by which others peri≈øh: The re≈øemblances of which are found no where in this World ≈øo agreeable and ≈øignificant, as in ≈øome Properties of little Children, and their Nature; the manly ≈øtate of Humane Nature, ≈øhewing ≈øo little hereof in this great Degeneracy, as to require a perfect Conver≈øion, and Regeneration to ≈øuch a ≈øtate.

2. The ≈øecond point of Truth is this, That whoever humbles him≈øelf, and becomes as ≈øuch a little Child, in tho≈øe Chri≈øtian Properties, is one of tho≈øe Great ones, tho≈øe Magnates; or the more any one humbles him≈øelf ≈øo, the greater he is; and he that humbles him≈øelf mo≈øt, is the greate≈øt in the Kingdom of Heaven, in the Kingdom of the Me≈ø≈øiah, and ≈øhall be in the Kingdom of Glory.

The≈øe two great Points of In≈øtruction being now ≈øettled upon this living Emblem, the Lord propo≈øes the very ≈øame to other two as great purpo≈øes of Admonition, although from another a≈øpect or ca≈øt of this one Picture: Con≈øider Little Ones, as the Emblems of Weakne≈øs, Infirmity, liablene≈øs to Danger and Injury, of little Defence and Re≈øi≈øtance to any A≈ø≈øault; and ≈øo the Lord declares:

1. Whoever receives ≈øuch a little one in his name, that is, upon the account of Profe≈ø≈øion of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, into a ju≈øt e≈øteem, value, and care, of cheri≈øhing ≈øuch a one in that Holy Profe≈ø≈øion, and ≈øecuring him, as far as he can, in the Ble≈ø≈øedne≈øs of that ≈øtate; receives, that is owns and acknowledges with Honour, Chri≈øt him≈øelf, and the kindne≈øs is accepted, as if it were immediately placed upon Chri≈øt.

2. But if any one Scandali≈øes, ≈øets a ≈øtone of Offence and Ruin, in the path of ≈øuch a Little One, by which he falls from, or in, his Profe≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øtianity to his De≈øtruction, the Lord pronounces a Woe upon ≈øuch a one, as dreadful as the Proverb imports, It were better that a Mil≈øtone were hung about his Neck, and he were ca≈øt into the depth of the Sea: Which as it peremptorily
dooms the Profe≈ø≈øed, ob≈øtinate Scandali≈øer, ≈øo it warns all of managing them≈øelves ≈øo in Chri≈øtianity, as to ca≈øt off all Offence and Scandal from it, and to encourage the tendere≈øt in it, to ≈øtrengthen, and promote them.
Hereby then, our Lord hath de≈øigned the ≈øecurity of the whole ≈øtate of Chri≈øtianity from the harm and danger of Scandal; for in the≈øe Little Ones he comprehends,

1. Tho≈øe, who in regard of their being newborn out of the State of Univer≈øal Scandal, are in danger of being re-intangled in its Net, or in regard of any other di≈øadvantage, or liablene≈øs to Scandals mi≈øchief, are the lo≈øt, as our Saviour after ≈øtiles them, and the weak, though not the young, (as the Apo≈øtle names them.) Now if ≈øuch are ≈øecured, all are ≈øecured: For if a Chri≈øtians carriage be ≈øo off from the danger of Scandali≈øing, as not to Scandali≈øe the weak, the ≈øtronger will be much le≈øs in danger to be offended.

2. Tho≈øe are the weak, and the Little Ones to us, who appear to us under any ≈øuch di≈øadvantage, though indeed they are not; as he that doubts, and dares not do what others profe≈øs to do on great a≈ø≈øurances, ≈øeems weak to them that doubt not, but are ≈øo a≈ø≈øured; and then the

3. The Term, Little Ones, expre≈ø≈øes a ≈øubordination under the Great Ones: Now that they may not a≈ø≈øume over the Little Ones, the Lord fir≈øt affirms, with his u≈øual A≈ø≈øeveration, that none can be Great, or any thing at all in his Kingdom, that is not humble and inoffen≈øive, as a Little One. But though our Lord was mo≈øt feelingly concerned, and ≈øtruck the mo≈øt ≈øtinging Woe into tho≈øe that Scandali≈øe them that believe in him; yet he did not overlook the World in general, but bewailed it peri≈øhing under Scandals, the multitude of Scandals, the inevitablene≈øs of Scandals, that they mu≈øt needs come, even impo≈ø≈øible they ≈øhould not come; and yet becau≈øe he knew what Spirit it is that acts Scandal, even from Satan the chief of Scandal, down through all the Mini≈øters of it, he heaps the Woe upon him by whom Scandal comes. And becau≈øe whoever Scandali≈øes others, is fir≈øt Scandali≈øed him≈øelf, and they al≈øo, that receive Scandal from others, have ≈øome great Scandal within, upon which that from without catches; he therefore ≈øo ≈øeverely cautions on all ≈øides again≈øt the Scandal of the Right Eye, the Right Hand, the Right Foot, and prefers to every mans choice the di≈ømembring any of them, rather than that the whole Body joyned to that Member, ≈øo fettered with Scandal, ≈øhould be ca≈øt into Hell, where their Worm dies not, and their Fire is never quenched, the dreadful end of Scandal.
Next follow the Arguments with which our Lord pre≈ø≈øes the highe≈øt value, and care over the lea≈øt of them that believe in him, not to offend them.

1. He ≈øhews at the ≈øame time, how honourable the Employment in ≈øerving the little ones is, and al≈øo of how dangerous a con≈øequence it is to de≈øpi≈øe them (which, both by the relation it hath to the Context, and the Apo≈øtles u≈øe of it, cannot be far from Scandali≈øing.) And the very mention of Angels brings to mind, the Charge they have over all ≈øuch, to bear them up in their hands, to guard them in all their ways, that they may not d ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ h their foot agin≈øt any of the ≈øtones of Scandal. They are Mini≈øtring Spirits, ≈øent forth to Mini≈øter for them that ≈øhall be Heirs of Salvation: Tho≈øe greate≈øt in the Kingdom of Heaven humble them≈øelves as Little Ones, to ≈øerve the Little Ones of God and Chri≈øt.

And, as their Angels, they always behold in Heaven the Father of our Lord, and of all that believe in him, that whoever de≈øpi≈øes them, even to Scandal, mu≈øt be ≈øure to have it remon≈øtrated again≈øt them.

2. He exemplifies the care of them in him≈øelf:
The Son of Man is come to ≈øeek and ≈øave that which is lo≈øt; and the Argument is rai≈øed to the height, as it is exemplified in the Father of the whole Family in Heaven and Earth, named after Chri≈øt; who≈øe will it is not, that ≈øo much as one (and yet when one only is in the danger of Scandal, Who does not look upon him as a Singulari≈øt, e≈øpecially if one of the lea≈øt too, and reject him?) ≈øhould peri≈øh, but is plea≈øed in the pre≈øervation of one ≈øuch; even as the joy of one Sheep, that is lo≈øt out of a hundred, exceeds ≈øen≈øibly the joy of the ninety nine that were not in hazard.

But now le≈øt the great charge again≈øt Scandali≈øing and De≈øpi≈øing ≈øhould ≈øeem to introduce a Lawle≈øs ≈øtate in Chri≈øtianity, and increa≈øe Petulancy, and Licentiou≈øne≈øs in tho≈øe, who would be looked upon as, at lea≈øt, Little Ones in Chri≈øtianity, or make the care of not Scandali≈øing of endle≈øs ≈øcruple, or burden; Our Lord pre≈øcribes a Method for preventing ≈øo ill Con≈øequences; very certain to its End, yet very far from Scandal or De≈øpi≈øing.
A Method that allows no ≈øin, and yet de≈øerts none, till they de≈øerve to be accounted but as Heathens or Publicans, to whom yet a due mea≈øure of Chri≈øtian Charity is to be pre≈øerved.

Which Method it is not my bu≈øine≈øs now to enter into the Controver≈øal part of, but to ob≈øerve, as of great moment, that the Doubting of the lawful u≈øe of Indifferent Things in Religion, falls not into the account of any of tho≈øe Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes the Lord ≈øpeaks of; and that, as if it were on purpo≈øe le≈øt the thing ≈øhould be mi≈øtaken, a mo≈øt different Method is in that Ca≈øe commanded by the Apo≈øtle of the Lord.
Here therefore give me liberty to compare, in ≈øome things which I have omitted in the body of the Di≈øcour≈øe, the Sermon of our Lord and his Apo≈øtle.

Fir≈øt, He that doubts in Indifferent Things, and cannot conform to what others do, and would be conformed to in, is not commanded by the Apo≈øtle to hear the one, or the two, or three, nor the Church it ≈øelf.

Nor is it ≈øaid by the Apo≈øtle, they that will not hear on ≈øuch accounts, ≈øhould be as Heathen-men, or Publicans, (or as we ≈øpeak, Excommunicate) both which are very notorious in the Evangeli≈øts Records, in the Ca≈øe of the Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes there ≈øpoken of, which a≈ø≈øures us they are of another Nature.

Nor doth the Apo≈øtle urge as from our Saviour, that what is in the≈øe Ca≈øes bound on Earth,
≈øhall be bound in Heaven; or what is loo≈øed on Earth, ≈øhall be loo≈øed in Heaven; that there ≈øhall be any obligation on the doubting Con≈øcience by the Churches Canons, or any ≈øuch di≈øcharge of it before God or it ≈øelf by obeying them: But every Man in this Ca≈øe is to hear his own Con≈øcience, there every thing of this nature is bound and loo≈øed; there every word or matter is heard and e≈øtabli≈øhed.

But the Apo≈øtle's command is, Fir≈øt, Not to Judge, or De≈øpi≈øe, if that may keep Indifferents to their Equipoi≈øe; if not, the Command is, not ≈øo much as by Example to Scandali≈øe, or draw any that Doubt to act again≈øt, or over their Doubt in Indifferent Things, becau≈øe they are but Indifferent; for that is to ≈øin again≈øt the Brethren, the weak Brethren; as at the lea≈øt we e≈øteem them: Now in the≈øe Ca≈øes, to ≈øin again≈øt the Brethren, is to ≈øin again≈øt Chri≈øt in his Law again≈øt Scandal.

Now in that all things are of ≈øo diver≈øe a frame and a≈øpect in the Lords Pre≈øcriptions concerning Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes, and the Apo≈øtle's Directions in ca≈øes of various apprehen≈øions in things of Indifferency,
wherein one great part may be guilty yet of great weakne≈øs and mi≈øtake, and that none of the Methods ordered in the one, is ≈øo much as mentioned in the other, or once intimated; it argues very evidently, that variety, and as various practices in indifferent Things, though joined with ≈øuch mi≈øtake and weakne≈øs, are none of the Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes our Saviour had regard to. And ≈øince the Apo≈øtle puts all under the notion of Scandal, wherein the weaker part is either drawn into ≈øin, enfeebled in the vigour, di≈øquieted in the true peace of Con≈øcience, or ≈øo much as de≈øpi≈øed, by being incompa≈ø≈øionately neglected in his Doubt; the whole Ca≈øe is brought under the force of our Saviour's Sermon again≈øt Scandal, that none looking upon them≈øelves on any accounts, as Great in the Kingdom of God, in the Church, or in the Chri≈øtian Profe≈ø≈øion (let tho≈øe Accounts be whatever they can be pre≈øumed to be) ≈øhould by any ≈øort of Imperiou≈øne≈øs, whether Command, rigorous Treaty, or Example, that de≈øpi≈øes all that do not follow it, impo≈øe upon the Little Ones.

To all which let me have the Readers patience to add this one Ob≈øervation, That the Evangeli≈øt Mark makes the occa≈øion of this, or a like Di≈øcour≈øe
of the Lords upon Scandal, That the Di≈øciples were much di≈øplea≈øed that one did ca≈øt out Devils in Chri≈øts name, that did not follow them, that did not ≈øeem, and indeed was not of their way, in the appearance of Things. But our Lord, with great Compa≈ø≈øion, accepts him ≈øo far as he was come. For, ≈øaith he, He that is not again≈øt us, is on our part. He that, although in a different Company, or Mode, does the ≈øame things we do, and does nothing in oppo≈øition to our Great De≈øign, is on our ≈øide. And ≈øo he proceeds into a ≈øimilar Di≈øcour≈øe of Kindne≈øs to, or Scandal again≈øt his Di≈øciples, though Little Ones. And if we ≈øuppo≈øe it the ≈øame Di≈øcour≈øe as in St. Matthew, and that this Evangeli≈øt had not an accurate regard to the occa≈øion; yet in that he connected it with ≈øuch an occa≈øion, and that by the Divine Wi≈ødom, it teaches us how much ≈øuch a Di≈øcour≈øe is adju≈øted to ≈øuch an occa≈øion; for guided by the Holy Spirit, the things are ≈øo laid together.

div.p: I Call this A Catechi≈øm, becau≈øe I de≈øign it a Familiar In≈øtruction in Fundamental Truths, Re≈øounding the ≈øame Thing from Que≈øtion to An≈øwer; the ea≈øie≈øt way of Conveying Truth, and Imprinting it upon the Minds of tho≈øe that are even of the meane≈øt Capacity: But e≈øpecially, becau≈øe the Principles of it are to be daily ≈øo Meditated upon, Pondered and Applyed to u≈øe, as to be a perpetual ≈øound in our Ears, and ≈øo to be properly ≈øtiled Catechi≈øm.

There is nothing we ≈øhould be more Rational in, than in the True Religion, the Account of which, and of its whole Content, ought to be ≈øo certain to us, that nothing of a Diver≈øe Spirit from it, can be added to it; nor any thing of its Integral or E≈ø≈øential Nature taken from it; but

To tho≈øe that have no Publick Character of Office or Magi≈øtracy. An≈øw. No: For ≈øome Parts of Religion are ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary to our very Natures, as Men, that they were concreated with us, and engraven upon our very Souls, and the immediate motions of our Faculties mu≈øt needs lead us to them, while right and ≈øtreight, and continuing in that perfect ≈øtate wherein our Creator left them.

For he looked upon all things that he had made, and behold all was good, and very good: And he appointed a Sabbati≈øm for all his Creatures, and e≈øpecially his Rational Creatures, the Morning Stars, to ≈øing together, and prai≈øe him for them.

But there are other Divine Truths, which are as the breaking up of the Great Deep of the Infinite Wi≈ødom, Grace, and Goodne≈øs of God, that can be known to the highe≈øt Under≈øtandings of Angels, or Arch-Angels, only by Revelation: Much le≈øs to Man, a Rea≈øon of a lower Orb, and lea≈øt of all, as fallen and corrupted.

Yet ≈øuppo≈øing the Souls of Men had abode in their fir≈øt Clearne≈øs and Lu≈øter, all his Faculties would have immediately received and adored God in all ≈øuch Manife≈øtations of him≈øelf, and Congratulated tho≈øe mighty Acce≈ø≈øions of Light and Truth.
Que≈øt. But what need was there of any Revelation, when Man was made perfect and good, while he continued ≈øo?

An≈øw. Revelation was even then nece≈ø≈øary, to ≈øhew, that it is not con≈øi≈øtent with the Nature of a Creature to have Happine≈øs and Perfection within it ≈øelf; but to be in continual dependence upon, and expectation from the Creator: For even that Perfection wherein Adam was made, was thus to maintain, continue, and a≈ø≈øure it ≈øelf; and ≈øo to ri≈øe to higher Perfection; He had therefore at fir≈øt a Doctrine by Revelation, ≈øutable to the two Sacramental Trees, ≈øo that though he was Perfect, as ≈øuch
a Creature without Sin, yet he was made with a po≈ø≈øibility of higher Advancement, and Perfection; as he was of falling from his pre≈øent Perfection, by not adhering to his Creator, according to what was revealed to him.
Que≈øt. What Relation do the≈øe two Records bear to one another, being both of God?

It is therefore impo≈ø≈øible, they ≈øhould either of them one contradict another, but that they unite with, confirm, and ju≈øtifie one another, and one pa≈øs out of, and repa≈øs into another; but the latter being more full, clear, and perfect, makes not only the Additions of what was not contained in the former, but does much inlighten and clear it; and ≈øince the Fall, it is no where el≈øe perfectly to be found, but in Revelation: Yet ≈øo, that whatever of it remains, or is reinkindled by Revelation, does both prepare a Man to receive, and does al≈øo a≈ø≈øure him the truth of Divine Revelation.
Que≈øt. You have ≈øhewed with what Wi≈ødom, Goodne≈øs, and excellent Contrivance, all things were laid by the Creator, let me now hear from you the u≈øe I am to make of it?

An≈øw. This teaches us to adore, applaud the Fidelity and Goodne≈øs of our Holy Maker, and to confe≈øs whatever di≈øorder hath invaded this State of things is owing altogether to the perver≈øene≈øs and weakne≈øs of Man, who≈øe De≈øtruction is of him≈øelf alone, and his help only in God, returning him to him≈øelf according to this fir≈øt De≈øignation.
Que≈øt. What then is the Supreme End of this Publick and Catholick Religion?

An≈øw. God, the Univer≈øal Being, receiving into his own mo≈øt Publick Glory, Life and Happine≈øs, the Univer≈øe of his Holy Creation, is Prai≈øed, Glorified, Enjoy'd, and admired in them, and by them, to Eternity.

div.head: CAP. II. Of the Violation of this Catholick Order of Religion, and the Means provided by God to re≈øtore it.
div.p: Que≈øt. HOw did a change begin in this Catholick State of Religion, in the place of which we now ≈øee endle≈øs Schi≈øme and Confu≈øion?

An≈øw. No: For God clothing him≈øelf in his Son, with the Compa≈ø≈øions of a Mediator and Redeemer, laid hold upon Humane Nature, as the Head of its Recovery, in that very Nature; certainly reconciling his own Seed, the Seed of Abraham, or his Church, into a ≈øtate more Catholick than the fir≈øt, He, God-Man, being ≈øo in≈øeparably united with it: And with a redundance of Grace to all Mankind, laid the Foundations of their Re≈øtoration to their fir≈øt Communion, with advantage, if built upon aright.
Que≈øt. What were the Foundations laid by the Son of God, the Saviour of all Men, e≈øpecially of them that believe, for the re≈øtoring them to the fir≈øt Catholick ≈øtate of Religion?

An≈øw. The very ≈øame that were Ordained by God before the Fall, viz. the Law of Natural Religion, pre≈øerved in the Soul, with direct A≈øpects upon God, Obligations to ≈øerve him, and De≈øires of his Favour.

And when Man found him≈øelf in a fallen e≈øtate, and under Guilt, and yet that God ≈øpared him, and had patience with him, there mu≈øt needs ari≈øe from True Rea≈øon, Hopes of and De≈øires after his Mercy and Pardon, and Motions of return to him by Repentance, as is plain in the King of Nineveh.

2. Revelation, mo≈øt exactly ≈øuited to our Recovery out of that mi≈øerable E≈øtate, with which God immediately ≈øuccour'd our Fir≈øt Parents again≈øt De≈øpair: For that was the Word of Promi≈øe, in relief again≈øt Satan's taking po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Man, as his Spoil; The Seed of the Woman ≈øhall break the Serpent's Head, an everla≈øting Enmity being immediately kindled between them.

The Divine Spirit alone, conducting us by Heavenly A≈ø≈øi≈øtances, inlightning us in the uncorrupted Principles of Natural Religion by Revealed, and a≈ø≈øuring to us Revealed Religion by its Intimate Union with Natural, and enabling us to cut the Lines of the one running into the other with innumerable Mazes of Union: Sometimes preparing us for Revealed Religion by Natural, always to the true Natural by Revealed, and ≈øo confirming them to us by one another.
Que≈øt. You have made no mention of Creation, Providence, Evidences of Divine Pre≈øence, and Miracles, what Place they have in the Renewal of Man's State towards God by the Redeemer.

The≈øe are all in the very ≈øame Place they were in the fir≈øt Settlement, attending the Doctrine and Divine Law they are to ≈øeal, with A≈ø≈øurances they are Divine, and giving the Image and Likene≈øs of that Law in the Power, Maje≈øty, Rectitude, and Order they them≈øelves carry, and ≈øo te≈øtifying of God, and his Word, of what Excellency it is; and that even before the Rea≈øon of Man, as it is imbodied, and mini≈øtred to by his Sen≈øes.

div.head: CAP. III. Of the Uncontrover≈øible Laws of Natural Religion.
div.p: Que≈øt. THere having been ≈øo much of Account given in general of Publick and Catholick Religion, ≈øhewing that it can be no other than what is from God; it is now nece≈ø≈øary to enter into a more particular Con≈øideration; and fir≈øt, what it is that remains Certain, and Evidently Publick; or, that is of God, in the Law written upon Man's Heart.
An≈øw. Whatever is indeed written in Man's Heart, mu≈øt certainly be from God; ≈øeeing no Created Hand could write there. The Hand that Made, can alone Ingrave it.
Que≈øt. How then ≈øhall we make a Judgment, what is written upon the Heart?

An≈øw. That which is univer≈øally acknowledged, and, amid≈øt all the Differences in Religion, falls under no Variation, a≈ø≈øures us, it was placed there by that Supreme Hand, that alike fa≈øhioned all Mens Hearts: and e≈øpecially, ≈øeeing to this univer≈øal Acknowledgment there is no Temptation from the ≈øen≈øual and wor≈øt Part of Man, it being again≈øt its Intere≈øt; but it ≈øprings from the wi≈øe≈øt and be≈øt Parts, mo≈øt unconcerned in this World, or any of the bruti≈øh Plea≈øures of it.
Que≈øt. What Principles do you account thus to be of Natural Religion?
An≈øw. I account the≈øe following;
That there is a God, the Greate≈øt and Be≈øt of Beings, that governs the World.
That God vouch≈øafes to be acknowledged, ador'd, and wor≈øhipped by Man; and that he takes notice when he is ≈øo wor≈øhipped, or neglected, and that with Favour, or Di≈øplea≈øure.
That there is a Di≈øtinction betwixt Good and Evil, ≈øetled by the Unchangeable Laws of God.
That God being him≈øelf ≈øo Good, is pleas'd in Men doing well, and rewards it; and di≈øpleas'd when Men do ill, and puni≈øhes it.
That Men have a Con≈øcience, viz. a Knowledg of, and Government of their own Actions, with Approbation of them if Good, and Di≈ølike if Bad.
That there are Rewards and Puni≈øhments beyond this Life.
That therefore the Notions of Virtue, Righteou≈øne≈øs, Temperance, Soberne≈øs, Beneficence, and the contrary Vices, are of unchangeable Truth, and the Actions flowing from them of the ≈øame Notion.
That God is both the Judge and Ob≈øerver of them now, and will be ≈øo in the Future State.
That in the time of God's Patience and Bounty to ≈øinful Man, there is Forgivene≈øs with him, that he may be feared: and that he thereby leads Men to Repentance.

That upon all accounts Solemn Wor≈øhip of him by Prayer, Prai≈øes, Honourable Di≈øcour≈øes of him, of all Obedience to him, and Returns to him after our Falls, are mo≈øt due from Humane Nature, and according to the ≈øociable Nature of Man in Publick A≈ø≈øociations.

An≈øw. I am fully a≈ø≈øured ≈øo; and that the≈øe, and all the immediate, genuine, and natural Deductions from them, are ≈øo nearly allied with Humane Nature, and Rea≈øon, that they are in no Parts of it wanting, however overcome; but where extreme Barbarity and Bruti≈øhne≈øs in all things el≈øe make it plain, ≈øuch People cannot weigh again≈øt the wi≈øer Societies of Mankind, in whom the more vigorous Efforts of Rea≈øon ≈øhew them≈øelves.

An≈øw. No, by no means: For, if Adam in Paradi≈øe had Revelation to make his State towards God Con≈øummate, how much more Man Fallen, in whom all Natural Light is but glimmering and ob≈øcure, Heavenly Objects at ≈øo great a remove, by his being ≈øunk down ≈øo low from them, and the Mi≈øts and Fogs of this Earth ≈øo prevalent upon him in the great Deordination of Spirit into Body, that whatever true Principles of Rea≈øon might effect, if duely pur≈øued, he is, without Revelation, upon all Experiment, no better than in the Valley of the Shadow of Death?

An≈øw. Very great; ≈øo that no Religion in the World hath been without the Pretence of it: And it is both mo≈øt hopeful according to the Laws of Natural Light, that God will reveal him≈øelf; and mo≈øt ju≈øt, that his Revelations ≈øhould be accepted with all Reverence, when vouch≈øafed: our very Rea≈øon being a Revelation from him; and if any Revelation from him could be fal≈øe, even That might be ≈øo al≈øo: But in all things, Natural Light mu≈øt needs bow to Divine Veracity.

An≈øw. Undoubtedly ≈øo: for the State of it could not

An≈øw. Very great, in many re≈øpects. 1. To ju≈øtifie God in his Dealings with Mankind, that there have been ≈øuch Po≈ø≈øibilities of Return to True Religion laid up in them. 2. To be as Sen≈øe in a Mans Soul, upon which all Divine Applications might take, either to Conviction, or Conver≈øion. 3. To be at all times ready to be re-enlivened by Revealed Truth, and to unite with it. 4. To be an Univer≈øal Code of True Religion, in which it is always rea≈øonable for Mankind to agree, or in any Parts of it, on any Occa≈øion, as Jonah and the Mariners did in their Calamity, or as St. Paul and the Seamen with him, in giving Thanks to God. 5. That Men may on all Occa≈øions treat with one another by it, on Terms of Rea≈øon and Ju≈øtice, as the Apo≈øtle Paul with the Men of Athens, with Felix; and generally Men one with another, in all their Commerce: All Society, good Laws and Government, Re≈øtraint of exce≈ø≈øive Evil, depending upon it.

div.head: CAP. IV. Of Revelation, and the Rea≈øons of ≈øo great Mi≈øcarriages again≈øt both the Light of Nature and Revelation, with the Means of Cure.
div.p: Que≈øt. SEeing there is, by all that hath been ≈øpoken, ≈øo great a weight re≈øting upon Revelation, let the Accounts of Gods Revealing him≈øelf to Mankind be more fully ≈øtated.

Yes, very early; how early we know not; but beyond Controver≈øie in the fir≈øt forming the Jewi≈øh Church into a ≈øetled Body, he began the more ≈øure and certain way of committing his Word and Will to Writing, and for the Honour of it, ≈øet the Copy with his own Hand, and continued it till the whole Revelation was compleat: Pa≈ø≈øant Revelation, or Oral Tradidition, not being ≈øure enough.

1. The unaccountablene≈øs of the Methods of Gods Government of the World, in the Efficacies of his di≈øtingui≈øhing Goodne≈øs, even when things ≈øeem equally di≈øpo≈øed to the advantage of one, as of another.

Thus many of the Fathers came over to Chri≈øtianity: And ≈øo in all parts of Scripture, by ri≈øing from the mo≈øt Fundamental Truths, lov'd and obey'd, a Man ≈øhall a≈øcend by due degrees to tho≈øe more remote. This is the mo≈øt damnable Antichri≈øtiani≈øm of Rome, to make its Private, Catholick. All Per≈øecutions of Heathens, Romes Inqui≈øition, and Ma≈ø≈øacres, have been

We mu≈øt then con≈øider, that if God does not miraculou≈øly interpo≈øe, it mu≈øt needs be ≈øo, it is no other than the Nece≈ø≈øity of the Ca≈øe, Men moving with ≈øo great Di≈øadvantages, as the Active Soul of Man does in ≈øo great a Concern as Religion is, in our highe≈øt Intere≈øt: and as thereupon Men will make u≈øe of it in the pre≈øent World, it mu≈øt needs be ≈øo: There mu≈øt be Here≈øies in Religion. That to the Soul humble, and fearing God, all that is of Grand Intere≈øt in Faith, Wor≈øhip, and Practice is ≈øo Publick, and evidently Divine, that no Man need be ever learning, and never come to the Knowledge of the Truth. div.head: CAP. V. Of the Publick or Divine Original of Sacred Writing, or Scripture.
div.p: Que≈øt. SEeing Scripture is the only Publick Record of True, Pure, Natural Religion, and more eminently of Revealed; it is mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary to be fully informed in all Points concerning it: And fir≈øt, What Care God hath been plea≈øed to take, that his Word, and purely that, ≈øhould be committed to Writing?

An≈øw. God held the Hands and Pens of Holy Men, by
an efficacious over≈øhadowing their Minds, and conducting all their Motions, that they could not erre: In ≈øome things he ≈øo fully po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed their Under≈øtandings and Affections with a full Knowledge and Sen≈øe of what they were to reveal, that they could not ≈øo much as mu≈øe any thing Strange or Diver≈øe from what they were ≈øo carried and born by the Divine Spirit in, even as Elijah in his Body.

In other things, wherein they could not look round about them, nor fully comprehend what the Spirit in them did ≈øignifie, though they convey'd it to After-times, yet they were by Almighty Impre≈ø≈øions upon all their Faculties nece≈ø≈øary to that Service, held in ≈øtronger than Adamantine Con≈øinements, that they could not extravagate from Divine Truths. Even Balaam, thus overpower'd again≈øt his will, could not go beyond the Word of the Lord, to ≈øpeak either Good or Evil, upon the greate≈øt Reward; much le≈øs Holy Men, who≈øe Wills were perfectly re≈øigned to the Divine Will.

Que≈øt. But was not there a Po≈ø≈øibility, tho≈øe Holy Men, Writers of Scripture, might at other times, when the Spirit was not ≈øo immediately pre≈øent to them, alter, or add of another Alloy, to what them≈øelves had been the In≈øtruments of conveying from God to the World? An≈øw. When once any Part of Divine Te≈øtimony was committed to Writing, it became a Boundary to tho≈øe very Penmen (much more to all others) that they were always concluded by it: So that be≈øides the Dread and Awe of God, and of the great Sin of Fal≈øification of his Truth or Name, they could not alter any thing, ≈øo as to di≈øagree with what they had before ≈øpoken by the Divine Spirit, who≈øe Righteous Judgments endure for ever: nor could they ≈øo much as imitate them≈øelves, when una≈ø≈øi≈øted by the Holy Spirit.

When therefore they did not under≈øtand by immediate A≈ø≈øi≈øtance, the utmo≈øt End and Reach of what them≈øelves were enabled to ≈øpeak and write, they did (and they could do no more) ≈øearch, and pronounce by all the be≈øt ordinary Helps God afforded them, but could change nothing, could add nothing; they ≈øearched what, or what manner of Time the Spirit of Chri≈øt in them did ≈øignifie; they could not pronounce of the Time, when not revealed to them: They knew the dreadful Anathema ready to fall, even upon an Angel from Heaven, that ≈øhould preach another Go≈øpel. The lea≈øt Iota, once e≈øtabli≈øhed by Unchangeable Wi≈ødom and Goodne≈øs, was le≈øs movable than Heaven and Earth, and would bear no Addition, but of the ≈øame Authority by which it ≈øelf was given.

And even the very Manner, Method, Words, as they meet to carry ≈øuch a Sen≈øe, have their Maje≈øty and Divinene≈øs; ≈øo that whatever was by In≈øpiration from God, bridled that which was not; and they that were in≈øpir'd, knew in what they were in≈øpir'd, and what they ≈øpoke as ≈øo in≈øpired, and in what they were not; but were as Sam≈øon with his Locks cut, no more than like other Men; and mo≈øt cautiou≈øly di≈øtingui≈øh'd betwixt the one and the other. Nothing therefore hath a≈ø≈øayed to joyn it ≈øelf to Scripture; if any hath dar'd to do it, it hath been rejected by it, when not of the High and Publick Spirit of it.
Que≈øt. But did not the Writers of the New Te≈øtament rever≈øe the Writings and Commands of the Old; which thing ≈øo ≈øcandali≈øed the Jews again≈øt our Lord, his Di≈øciples, and Go≈øpel?

An≈øw. No otherwi≈øe than as the Sun commands the Shadow to fly away, and the le≈ø≈øer Lights to retire, when it ≈øelf appears; or the things typ'd out being come, make u≈øele≈øs the Types, ≈øo that they nece≈ø≈øarily give place, or, as Pictures vail when the Life is pre≈øent: El≈øe there was ≈øuch a Re≈øpect to the Scriptures of the Old Te≈øtament in

Upon which account, the Apo≈øtle calls them the more ≈øure Word of Prophe≈øie; more ≈øure, becau≈øe of greater Antiquity, and Elder Reception into Scripture, than that Hi≈øtorical Relation and Doctrine, which yet was immediately to pa≈øs into Scripture of the ≈øame Authority and Value with former Scripture, and of greater Evidence and Divine Clearne≈øs, and recommended by Higher Appearances of Divinity.

And on this ≈øame account the New Te≈øtament derives it ≈øelf from the Old, ≈øometimes by Proofs out of it, drawn according to the mo≈øt regular Trains and Con≈øequences; ≈øometimes by more immediate and autho ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ tative Interpretation, but of the ≈øame Publick and Divine In≈øpiration with the Prophecy of Old Time it ≈øelf, as ≈øhall be pre≈øently more fully di≈øcours'd under the Head of Interpretation.
Que≈øt. How far, and to what things does the Rule of the Word of God extend?

An≈øw. To all things, mo≈øt a≈ø≈øuredly, that are nece≈ø≈øary to Salvation and Eternal Life, or to the true perfecting the Con≈øcience in Purity and Peace; whether they are things to be believed, as the Springs of Heavenly Action; or Things to be ob≈øerved in the Wor≈øhip of God, or to guid ‚Ä¢ the Practice, and order the Conver≈øation aright to tha ‚Ä¢ Salvation; or that are pre≈øcribed according to the Will of God, for Di≈øcipline and Government of the Church: Al ‚Ä¢ the≈øe are plainly written, or by ju≈øt Con≈øequences to b ‚Ä¢ derived from the Word of God, ≈øo far as they are nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øhew Men the way to plea≈øe God, or to a≈ø≈øure them

div.head: CAP. VI. Of the Proof of Scripture, That it is of God; and that the Proof al≈øo is Publick and Divine.
div.p: Que≈øt. WHat kind of Proof of ≈øo Divine a Record as Scripture, is high enough to prove it to be ≈øo Divine?

An≈øw. 1. Becau≈øe it is below the Dignity of Divine, to receive its principal Proof from Private, or lower than Divine or Publick.

3. Becau≈øe it is impo≈ø≈øible what is truly Divine ≈øhould not dart the Rays of Divinity, as all other Things of Excellency ≈øend out the Beams of that Excellency they have, and thereby di≈øcover them≈øelves; For, we know all things e≈øpecially by them≈øelves. Be≈øt and Greate≈øt is ≈øelf-evidently Divine; and whatever it is written upon, is evidently Divine al≈øo.

An≈øw. I account this the Chief; That there are Two great Volumes, the Book of the Natural Law of Religion, written upon the Heart, and engraven in the Con≈øcience; and the Book of Scripture: That both the≈øe are addre≈ø≈øed purely to the Mind, as ab≈øtracted from Sen≈øe: That each of them is Counterparted by Two great Manife≈øtations of Divinity to Sen≈øe, which Sen≈øe is Rea≈øon incarnate, or Mind acting in and by Body. An≈øw. All that can be de≈øired to be allowed; for it ≈øpeaks the Ab≈øolute Sovereignty of God, in making u≈øe of whom and what he plea≈øes, in introducing his Word into any Parts of the World, and contriving the Te≈øtimony of Men as preparatory to the Te≈øtimony from him≈øelf, which is much greater; even as our Saviour received the Service of John's Te≈øtimony, but had much higher; or as Rea≈øon may receive from Sen≈øe ≈øome accidental Te≈øtimonies.

Que≈øt. But is there not much more to be yielded to the Rational A≈ø≈øurance, that ≈øuch Hi≈øtorians as the Prophets, Apo≈øtles, and In≈øpired Writers, of ≈øuch Hone≈øty and Integrity, would not prevaricate, nor give any fal≈øe Account of Things,
of the Miracles wrought by them≈øelves or our Saviour, of the Doctrines of Chri≈øtianity, or of their Divine Original; e≈øpecially when they ≈øeal'd all the≈øe with the Contempt of all things in this World, even of Life it ≈øelf, and died in the con≈øtant Affirmation of them; which remov'd all ba≈øe De≈øigns far from them, even the ≈øu≈øpicion of it?

An≈øw. The≈øe Proofs of the Doctrine and Divine De≈øcent of Scripture, are undoubtedly of the highe≈øt Account that any Created Te≈øtimony can be, and are a down-weight of Proof to all ≈øober Rea≈øon: Yet that they can ri≈øe above the Value of John Bapti≈øt's Te≈øtimony to Chri≈øt, I cannot find; and therefore we mu≈øt remove higher to the Doctrines that tho≈øe Holy Men preach'd and writ, the ≈øpiritual Wi≈ødom and admirable Contexture they us'd in Writing, the Works they did, carrying the Evidences of Divinity in them≈øelves, and applied by the Holy Spirit to the Sen≈øes of true Believers, with its own a≈ø≈øuring Atte≈øtations, and gracious Operations: of which, all that was but created is no more than the Tube, Pipe, or Channel of Conveyance, if we enter it into a compare with what is Higher and Divine.

But if the la≈øt Re≈øolution of Proof were into any thing Humane, there might be mi≈øtake in that; for Humane at its highe≈øt elevation is but Created, and Created is not firm and ≈øure enough for a Foundation, nor can it rai≈øe an A≈ø≈øent noble and generous enough for a Faith in that which is Divine. Que≈øt. How comes it to pa≈øs, that there are ≈øuch different Degrees of Scripture-Excellency in the ≈øeveral Parts of it, and that it is not one Even Form of Doctrine, methodically laid together, and of the ≈øame Tenour of Di≈øcour≈øe.

In this ≈øeeming Di≈øorder appears the great Wi≈ødom and Maje≈øty of Divine Contrivance, that without obliging it ≈øelf to the low and even pedantick Laws of Humane Di≈øcour≈øe, it rai≈øes ≈øo great a Record of Truth upon variety of Occa≈øions, and by an Infinite Fore≈øight predetermining to it ≈øelf the ≈øeveral Mea≈øures and Ends of Scripture, rai≈øes them out of a great variety of Accidents, and in ≈øuch an Order as ≈øeem'd be≈øt to it ≈øelf for tho≈øe Ends, ≈øo as to give ea≈øie and ready Advantages to him that runs to read, and gather In≈øtructions of weightie≈øt moment, and al≈øo of quicke≈øt and ≈øuddene≈øt ≈øally upon his Mind, of greate≈øt aptne≈øs to fix upon the Memory without loading it, and yet in the mean time to lay the Obligations of all Degrees of Search and Diligence to join one part of Scripture to another, ≈øo as to comprehend the whole Complex of Divine Doctrine, and extract the Order of Hi≈øtory. For by a mo≈øt natural, free, and unaffected occa≈øional way, all Truths to make wi≈øe to Salvation, and a complete Sum of all Goodne≈øs, is to be found in Scripture, with infinite Varieties of Addre≈øs, all the ways po≈ø≈øible, to the Under≈øtanding,
Will, Affections, Con≈øcience, Memory, Imagination, ≈øuited to all Capacities, States, Conditions, full of plain and obvious, of mo≈øt retir'd, ≈øecret, and farthe≈øtreach'd Wi≈ødom, which no Mind can fully gra≈øp, nor Tongue expre≈øs.

And with the≈øe Things of main Importance, runs along ≈øuch a Chronology of the Dealings of God with the World, and e≈øpecially with his Church, as ≈øerves the main De≈øign. All Learning and Knowledge in the mean time attending with lowlie≈øt Submi≈ø≈øion, and not with pompous Appearance.

Now from this Supreme Di≈øpo≈øe of all things to the Ends of God in Scripture, out of ≈øuch a variety of Emergencies of all ≈øorts, ari≈øes ≈øuch a diver≈øity of ≈øeveral Excellencies in the Parts of Scripture, that yet all meet in that Great Center of the Glory of God, in a Communication of his Coun≈øels concerning Man, and that turn round tho≈øe Two Globes, that little one of the pre≈øent World, a Point like this Earth, and the other that va≈øt Circumference of Eternity.
Que≈øt. But is there not as great a difference ari≈øing from the various States and Conditions of the Writers of Scripture, and the ≈øo different Periods of Time they were upon?

An≈øw. That there is, and mu≈øt needs be a difference, is undeniable; yet, to the great Glory of Scripture, and a≈ø≈øurance it is from God, even tho≈øe ≈ømalle≈øt and lowe≈øt things la≈øt ≈øpoken of are all treated with all the Purity, Gravity, becoming the Penmen of the Holy Spirit, and with all the U≈øefulne≈øs their Nature can extend to; Even ≈øo the Holy Men u≈øed by God in this Service, how various and differing ≈øoever in their ≈øeveral Ages and Times of writing, in their Circum≈øtances of State and Condition in this World, High, Low, Rich, Poor, Learned, Unlearned, how di≈øtant ≈øoever in their Times of Writing, in the outward Forms and Modes of their Wor≈øhip of God, in the
Things that fell under their Account and Relation, before the Law, under the Law, in the Days of the Me≈ø≈øiah, after his Death; yet there is the ≈øame Spirit, Scope, Cha≈øtne≈øs of Style, Maje≈øty, and Authority in the Contexture; one A≈øpect upon the Glory of God, Obedience to him, De≈øire of his Favour, as the whole Happine≈øs of Man; the ≈øame Reflexions upon the great Evil of Sin, and the con≈øequent Mi≈øery, and even of their own Sins: So that where any Combination, or Conference to concert things, was impo≈ø≈øible, yet there is ≈øuch an Union without a ≈øet Uniformity, as a≈ø≈øures the One Hand of the Divine Spirit and Guidance upon All.
Que≈øt. Is not the Church of God the Tru≈øtee and Depo≈øitory of Sacred Oracles?

An≈øw. It is ≈øo in Divine Ordination, and the general Cour≈øe of Providence; but yet it adds nothing to them, but receives all from them. The Church is known to be the Church by the Scriptures, not the Scriptures by the Church, except declaratorily only. The Church is the Pillar and Re≈øt of Scriptures, where God is pleas'd to fix them, that they may be expo≈øed to Publick View; but their Authority is of God, evident in them≈øelves.
Que≈øt. Do we then attribute nothing more to the Church, in which we were Baptiz'd, and received the Knowledge of Religion?

An≈øw. A very great Favour it is of God, that when he writes up the People, he counts that we were born within his True Church, where all the Springs of Salvation run: but as to the Proof of Religion, or the Records of it, it can be no more than a Private Proof: For, till we make a true Judgment, by what is Divine and Publick, and of God in the true Church, it does no more than equal other Societies walking with Confidence and A≈ø≈øurance, with great Awes and Devotion, in the Name of their God, in the Profe≈ø≈øion of their Religion. Till therefore there
is a Trial of every Religion, and the Records of it, all ≈øuch Societies are upon the ≈øame Level. When the Religion, and Oracles of every Religion, come to be tried, and duely examined, the Church of God ri≈øes to Heaven, and all el≈øe, except ≈øo far as they joyn in any Parts of the ≈øame Truth, ≈øink down beneath.
Que≈øt: But how can we know that every Book of Scripture is Scripture, but by the Te≈øtimony of the Church? or, that we have all the Books of it, but by the ≈øame Te≈øtimony?

An≈øw. That the Books we own for Scripture are Scripture, and all of them ≈øo, ari≈øes to our A≈ø≈øurance by finding the ≈øame Divine Spirit of Truth running through one, as does through another: For, upon this account the True Church received them, when fir≈øt received, and ≈øo tran≈ømitted them, making the ≈øame Judgment ≈øucce≈ø≈øively in the ≈øeveral Ages, as the fir≈øt did, the ≈øame Rea≈øon always continuing. What is be≈øides this, is to be attributed to the Di≈øcerning of Spirits in all the Times while Scripture was writing, by the due Exerci≈øe of which True Scripture was received, and all other ≈øhut out: for, the Writings of Prophets was ≈øubject to Prophets, and by them enroll'd into Scriptures. That we have the ≈øame Scripture ju≈øtly and faithfully con≈øigned over to us from Age to Age, is to be own'd and acknowledg'd to Divine Providence watching over his Church and Oracles together, and conveying to us by the ordinary Security of the Churches Te≈øtimony, the Precious di≈øtingui≈øh'd not only from the Vile, but from the le≈øs Precious al≈øo: but yet we mu≈øt have greater Te≈øtimony than this, as hath been already urged.
Que≈øt. But how could we be a≈ø≈øured we have all the Scripture, were it not for the Churches Te≈øtimony?

An≈øw. Finding ≈øo much Divine, and no more of the ≈øame ≈øtamp in the World, we may be concluded that way, and abundantly ≈øatisfied, that God will accept us in our Faith and Obedience to ≈øo great a Revelation. When any mea≈øure
of Divine Truth hath been adhered to ≈øincerely, the Danger hath always been greater in lo≈øing True Religion by corrupt Additions; and the injurious Refu≈øals of further Revelation come to pa≈øs more through the Prejudices of that Corruption, than by humble and mode≈øt Su≈øpen≈øions, till God hath a≈ø≈øured us of his further Revelations. But be≈øides this, we may ea≈øily find, we mu≈øt needs have the whole Globe of Truth, and the Horizon of the Go≈øpel gives us the whole Heaven or Kingdom of it, as it is admini≈øtred in this World; ≈øo that all further Degrees of Light, and Di≈øcoveries of it, ≈øhall be but greater Clearne≈ø≈øes of what we already have in the main and Sub≈øtance: For, if even the New Te≈øtament, though it made ≈øo great a change, did but thus compleat and illu≈øtrate Chri≈øt ye≈øterday and to day the ≈øame, how much more may we be a≈ø≈øured, who have the New it ≈øelf, ≈øo much excelling the Old, as it every where a≈ø≈øures us? So that we can expect a Milennium, or the New Hieru≈øalem on Earth, only for the highe≈øt Exaltation of what we now have, till we come to Heaven it ≈øelf.
Que≈øt. Do the various Readings, ≈øo often bandied by Learned Men, make no Abatement from the Certainty of Scripture?

An≈øw. Tho≈øe various Readings are ≈øuch as excite and quicken Search, and yet cannot di≈øtract the Doctrine, being not able to alter the Scope, Coherence, and De≈øign of the Context, much le≈øs to change the Analogie of Scripture in other Places: While therefore they do not that, they take away the ≈øu≈øpicion of Con≈øpiracy, they pre≈øerve from greater Corruptions, by turning the Eyes of Men to look every way; they ≈øhew how many excellent Sen≈øes dwell near the Divine Writing, and the Bad are manife≈øtly enough thrown off: For in main things there is ≈øo much repeated, and ≈øaid over again and again, as that all ≈øuch Truths may be fully pre≈øented and a≈ø≈øured, and yet not ≈øo much be ≈øaid, as might be ≈øaid of the ≈øame kind,
without any Tautology; for the Subjects are ≈øo rich, that even the World would be over-charg'd, and not able to contain the Books that would be written. Amen.

div.head: CAP. VII. Of the Publick Interpretation of Scripture.
div.p: Que≈øt. THat the Progre≈øs upon this great Point may be made with the be≈øt Advantage, it will be nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øtate the Amount of what hath been already a≈ø≈øerted, viz. That Scripture is a Publick and Divine Record; and, That the Proof and Evidence it is Divine, is Divine and Publick al≈øo: What therefore do the≈øe two Po≈øitions ari≈øe to?

An≈øw. They ari≈øe plainly to this; 1. That True Religion is at once given, unalterably fixed on Monuments of its own, and cannot receive the various Pha≈øes of Increa≈øe or Decrea≈øe, like the Moon, by new and up≈øtart Decrees, Canons, or Anathemas. 2. That Religion is in this Sen≈øe Publick, even as God him≈øelf, that it is of free and open acce≈øs in the Scripture, and its Entertainment as liberal as the Light and the Fountains of Water; and no Man need wait till his Religion be drawn out of the private Repo≈øitory of Brea≈øt or Brea≈øts. 3. That the A≈ø≈øurance and Evidence of Scripture is very near us, when we come to treat with it; ≈øo that we need not ≈øend up to Heaven, that were to bring Scripture down from above, when it is come down already; nor beyond the Sea, to olde≈øt Antiquity, for a Scale to it, which hath always the Broad Seal of Divinity with it; for that were to bring Scripture a ≈øecond time from the Apo≈øtles and former Ages, through which
Divine Care and Providence hath already pa≈øs'd it down to us, with the very ≈øame principal A≈ø≈øurance it gave them, viz. that Divine Life of Truth and Holine≈øs that cannot be far from any one of us; for in it our Under≈øtandings and Con≈øciences live, and move, and have their Beings, and in that Light alone ≈øee Light.

Que≈øt. But hath the Private Spirit of Apo≈øtate Angels, working by Corrupted Humane Nature, made no Attempt upon this Publick Record, though ≈øo every way guarded, as it is, to introduce a Fal≈øe Religion, even under the Appearance of this Publick Authority of Scripture?
An≈øw. Yes; that very notorious one of Private Interpretation.
An≈øw. What is Private Interpretation?

An≈øw. That it may be well under≈øtood, being a very great In≈øtrument of the Fal≈øe Spirit, we mu≈øt proceed by degrees to the true Comprehen≈øion of it: And fir≈øt, in the ≈øtrictne≈øs of its Notion, it is an affixing a Sen≈øe to Scripture, or any part of it, that does not ≈øo evidently and indi≈øputably flow from Scripture, as to partake of the Divinity of Scripture.
Que≈øt. How ≈øhould an Interpretation be ≈øo made of Scripture, as to partake of its Divinene≈øs?

An≈øw. An Interpretation is as Divine as Scripture, when it is the true evident Importance and Sen≈øe of Scripture Words and Scope, and carries the perfect Spirit and Analogie of Scripture with it, or is a Deduction and Doctrine ari≈øing from Scripture, mea≈øured by the Context by its u≈øual ways of expre≈ø≈øing it ≈øelf, and the compare of one Place of Scripture with another, ≈øo as to evince it ≈øelf to be a ju≈øt and nece≈ø≈øary Con≈øequence.
Que≈øt. What is the Effect of ≈øuch Interpretations?
An≈øw. Every one that ≈øoberly, and impartially, and piou≈øly attends to it, cannot but be convinced and in≈øtructed by it, as the true Divine Scripture-Sen≈øe, opened and applied to him.
Que≈øt. How el≈øe may Interpretation be Publick and Divine, even as Scripture it ≈øelf?

An≈øw. When there is truly a Divine Pre≈øence, and ≈øuch Motives of Credibility by which a rightly qualified Per≈øon may be induced to believe, that ≈øuch an Interpreter is immediately a≈ø≈øi≈øted by the Holy Spirit to give ≈øuch an Interpretation, that el≈øe could not be found by any Created Sagacity or Indu≈øtry, in ≈øuch particular Places of Scripture, either from the Importance of the Words, the ≈øtrength of the Context, or Scope, or in the Analogie of Scripture, comparing Spiritual things with Spiritual.
Que≈øt. What are to be under≈øtood to be Motives of Credibility in ≈øo great a Ca≈øe?

An≈øw. The Divine Sen≈øe of an Interpretation, agreeable with all tho≈øe ≈øo ≈øelf-evident Notions of God, and all Goodne≈øs; the Weight and Gravity of the Matter; The Authoritativene≈øs of Scripture Language and Elocution; Miracles; Agreement with all former Scripture; Awes upon the Con≈øcience; Inward Illumination of the Holy Spirit, in its Sanctifying and Heavenly Influences breathing in it, and with it. The≈øe are a Divine and Publick Pre≈øence, and ab≈øolutely con≈øtitute further Scripture, even as they illu≈øtrate and put a greater Splendour upon former Scripture, and compleat it.
Que≈øt. Who were ≈øuch Interpreters of former Scripture?

An≈øw. The Prophets were ≈øuch Interpreters upon the Law in their Time, even all that writ after Mo≈øes, who either by Hi≈øtories, compiled by ≈øuch Divine In≈øpiration, gave Examples agreeable to the Scope of the Law, or by Sermons ≈øtirr'd up to the Obedience of it, and reproved the Di≈øobedience; or by Divine Meditations, Di≈øcour≈øes, and Hymns, di≈øplay'd it; or by Prophe≈øies foretold the Government of God in his Church, and in the World according to it; but e≈øpecially accommodated all things in it under Prophetick Veils, to Chri≈øt, and the State of True
Religion under the New Te≈øtament: All the Prophets from Samuel, and all that followed after, as many as have ≈øpoken, foretold likewi≈øe of the≈øe days: All which together fill up wholly the Spaces of Scripture in the Old Te≈øtament.
Que≈øt. How did the New Te≈øtament, and the Writers of it, ≈øucceed in this great Office of Expounding and Summing up Scripture in this Publick Divine Authority?

An≈øw. They were above all that went before them: For, John the Bapti≈øt, than whom a greater Prophet among them that were born of Women had not ri≈øen, yet he that was lea≈øt in the Kingdom of God, in the more explained State of Chri≈øtianity, was greater than he.
Que≈øt. How is this Notion of Publick Interpretation, contradi≈øtingui≈øh'd to Private, made good out of Scripture it ≈øelf?

An≈øw. From the Apo≈øtle Peter, who expre≈øly tells us, Scripture is not of any Private Interpretation: Who≈øe Sen≈øe in that place is very nece≈ø≈øary to be pur≈øued, both as it much clears the Nature of Private Interpretation, and al≈øo ≈øtrengthens the Foundations of the New Te≈øtament, as laid in the Old.

Que≈øt. But you know the Original Word there u≈øed, and tran≈ølated Interpretation, is by ≈øome under≈øtood for no more than the Prophetick Declaration, or Interpreting the Mind of God, revealed by In≈øpiration; and by very many, another Word ≈øignifying In≈øpiration it ≈øelf, o ‚Ä¢ the Illap≈øe of the Divine Spirit in tho≈øe Prophetick Revelations, is preferred to the Word tran≈ølated Interpretation, as the more genuine Reading.

An≈øw. I know the Current of Expo≈øitors both the ways you mention; but again≈øt them both there is this great Rea≈øon: No other but Interpretation, and that ≈øtrictly taken, will fit the Apo≈øtles Purpo≈øe.
Que≈øt. What was the Apo≈øtles Purpo≈øe?
An≈øw. To a≈ø≈øure the Jewi≈øh Chri≈øtians in the Truth of Chri≈øtianity, out of that more ≈øure Word of Prophe≈øie in the Old Te≈øtament.
Que≈øt. Was it not then to the purpo≈øe, to a≈ø≈øure the Divine Original of that Word of Prophe≈øie, and to a≈ø≈øert its immediate De≈øcent from the Publick Holy Spirit?

An≈øw. That indeed was nece≈ø≈øarily ≈øuppos'd and included, or rather concluded on all hands; but not the clo≈øe Point in di≈øcour≈øe: For, the Sacredne≈øs of the Old Te≈øtament being agreed both by Jews and Chri≈øtians, the Apo≈øtle commends the giving heed to it, as to a Light that ≈øhone in a dark place, a great Lamp ≈øhining when all was dark and deep Night about, till the Day of the Go≈øpel dawn'd, and Chri≈øt, the Day-≈øtar, aro≈øe in their Hearts by Faith.
Que≈øt. What was the preci≈øe Mark the Apo≈øtle was to aim at?
An≈øw. To vindicate the true way of Interpreting this ≈øure Word of Prophefie.
Que≈øt. Why was this ≈øo much to his purpo≈øe?
An≈øw. Becau≈øe the whole Stream of Interpretation of the Old Te≈øtament among the Jews run again≈øt Chri≈øtianity.
Que≈øt. Whence came this Current of Fal≈øe Interpretation?

An≈øw. Even from whence Interpretation might ≈øeem lea≈øt of all to de≈øerve the name of Private, from the Scribes and Phari≈øees, Doctors of the Law, Elders of the People, who vogued them≈øelves the Publick, and ≈øo Proprietors of the Sen≈øe and Interpretation of the Scriptures; but, as our Saviour ≈øays, they had indeed taken away this true Key of Knowledge, neither entring in them≈øelves, nor ≈øuffering tho≈øe that would.
Que≈øt. How does the Apo≈øtle vindicate this Point?

An≈øw. By a vehement Caution on tho≈øe to whom he writ, to mea≈øure from the Publick and Divine Original of Scripture, to the Interpretation, as nece≈ø≈øarily to be Publick
and Divine al≈øo; You do well (≈øaith he) to take heed to the Word of Prophe≈øie of the Old Te≈øtament, as yet more ≈øure to you than the New can be; if you do but know and well con≈øider this fir≈øt, and lay it in the Foundation, That Scripture cannot be ≈øubject to a Private Intetpretation, who≈øe Original you your ≈øelves, together with us, acknowledge as Publick as the Holy Spirit: For, can that be ≈øubject to the Will and Di≈øpo≈øe of Man in the Interpretation, that came not by the Will of Man, but by the Supreme Motion of the Holy Gho≈øt, in the Original?
Que≈øt. Wherein lies the Strength of this Argument?

An≈øw. In this: If the Interpretation of Scripture be not as high as the Original, ≈øo high an Original is to no purpo≈øe: For Sen≈øe being more Scripture than Words, and Interpretation a≈ø≈øigning the Sen≈øe, if That be Private, All is Private at the Rebound, and not Divine: el≈øe a Divine Original ≈øhall be mi≈ømatch'd, controll'd, and even made ≈øervile by and to a Private, and often a Fal≈øe and Unworthy Interpretation.
Que≈øt. Into what ∆≤≈øe and Effect did this Argument i≈ø≈øue?

An≈øw. To a ≈øilent calling them to compare the Manner and Kind of Interpretation u≈øed by the Lord and his Apo≈øtles, and that other of the Jewi≈øh Doctors, and then to ‚Ä¢ udge which appeared Divine, and from God, which not; and they would ea≈øily give the Preference to our Lord and his Mini≈øters, as the only Divine Interpreters.
Que≈øt. How then did our Saviour and the Apo≈øtles ju≈øtifie their Interpretation to be Publick and Divine?

An≈øw. By one of the two fore-named ways; either from the evident Importance of ≈øome very expre≈øs Scriptures of the Old Te≈øtament, applied in the New; as David's calling Chri≈øt (who was his Son) Lord, which muzled the very Adver≈øaries; or by the immediate Pre≈øence of the Divine Spirit, di≈øcovering what it had trea≈øured and ≈øealed up in ≈øuch Expre≈ø≈øions, which Eye could not ≈øee, nor Heart conceive,
till in due time the Spirit it ≈øelf revealed them: The Spirit, that knows its own Depths; the Spirit, to whom are known all its own De≈øigns, from the fir≈øt Foundations or Beginning of Scripture, to the highe≈øt Stone in the Structure, or End of it: The Top is known to it in the very Bottom; the End, in the Beginning. That therefore which was ≈øeen to Men only in the Rudiment or Foundation, and ≈øeem'd to mean no more, appeared at that very time to him in the Complement, and he applies it to that Complement, as certainly and ju≈øtly as they did to the fir≈øt Rudiment or Foundation: As, Out of Egypt have I called my Son, was as truly applied to Chri≈øt's coming out of Egypt, being then come to its Perfection of Sen≈øe, as it was applied to I≈ørael coming out of Egypt in the fir≈øt Rudiment; and the Divine Spirit as truly meant the la≈øt as the fir≈øt, though none could know its Sen≈øe but it ≈øelf, till it ≈øelf revealed it.
Que≈øt. How could it be proved the Mini≈øters of the New Te≈øtament had the true Key of Interpretation committed to them by the Spirit?

An≈øw. By the concurrence of all things that ju≈øtified the fir≈øt Writers of Scriptures to be Commi≈ø≈øioned by God; Great and weighty Truth, Holy, Heavenly, becoming God, as the Author; ≈øuch Speech, as none be≈øide the Writers of Scripture ever ≈øpoke; all of a piece with former Scripture; Miracles; mighty Efficacy upon Con≈øciences; the Glory of God; the Salvation of Souls; the aboli≈øhing of Sin, the Ends de≈øigned in all; the removing all lower Forms and Ceremonies for the time being, into a mo≈øt High, Spiritual, Sub≈øtantial Religion; True Peace of Con≈øcience introduced. The≈øe, with innumerable others, concurring in any Interpretation of former Scripture, that could not el≈øe be found out in its full Meaning, do both enlighten former Scripture, and enlarge it into further and more Scriptures.

Que≈øt. If then our Lord and his Apo≈øtles, in Interpreting the Old Te≈øtament by the immediate Pre≈øence of the Holy Spirit, re≈øting without mea≈øure on our Saviour, and in full mea≈øures on the Apo≈øtles, di≈øcover'd that Sen≈øe in the Ancient Scriptures which was indeed depo≈øited there, but could not be unlock'd by any Created Wi≈ødom; it will follow thence, That it is an unnece≈ø≈øary Labour of many Worthy Expo≈øitors of Scriptures, to pre≈øs too hard in every Quotation of the Old Te≈øtament we find in the New, for a free and full Confe≈ø≈øion of all that Sen≈øe it there expre≈ø≈øes, as if it could naturally ari≈øe from ≈øo many Words and Syllables ≈øo put together, having power and vertue by them≈øelves to ≈øignifie ≈øo high; ≈øince the Holy Spirit had a reach in them, which none could gra≈øp or fathom, but it ≈øelf; and contriv'd that Sen≈øe ≈øo into Words, as none could ≈øummon it but it ≈øelf; and that it re≈øted upon the Lord and his Apo≈øtles to bring it to light, and reveal it into New and Higher Scriptures; and that it appears as undeniably they did ≈øo, as that the Old Te≈øtament it ≈øelf is Scripture.

An≈øw. The Indu≈øtry of ≈øuch Worthy Per≈øons is not to be blamed, to trace the Sen≈øe of the New Te≈øtament in the Words of the Old, as far as it is po≈ø≈øible for them to go: But if they cannot give Satisfaction to cavelling Athei≈øts, or Infidels, or to the Scruples of Good Men, it ≈øtill remains a ju≈øt Ground of Satisfaction: The Spirit, that carried, by an Almighty Hand, the Writers of the Old Te≈øtament, carried tho≈øe Penmen of the New by the ≈øame al≈øo; and from one ≈øingle Glance of its Meaning, that it ≈øelf, with Divine Artifice, had left drawn there, it derives that full Face of Truth in the New, to be its Sen≈øe in the Old, than that Sam≈øon's Riddle in the Expo≈øition, ≈øhould be his Sen≈øe in the dark Cover of it in Words that could not el≈øe import it. He that created the Words in the Old Te≈øtament, and even then in≈øpired them with that Divine≈øt Sen≈øe, as with Life,
might yet ≈øuffer it to lie intoomb'd in them, till it ≈øelf, that entru≈øted it there, gave it a Re≈øurrection in the New.

Que≈øt. But would you have none undertake in the Interpreting or Expounding Scripture, except by In≈øpiration, or the Evidences of immediate Divine Pre≈øence, where either Scripture is not ≈øo expre≈øs as to be its own undoubted Interpreter, or the Interpretation deduced as evidently as any Con≈øequence by Rea≈øon?

An≈øw. Far be it from me to di≈øcourage or le≈ø≈øen ≈øuch Undertakings; I rather wi≈øh all the Lord's People thus far Prophets, to ≈øearch the Meaning of Scripture, with all the Helps and Advantages they can attain; and that in the mean time all tho≈øe who have any part of the Prophetick Office upon them, would read and meditate day and night, to Interpret Scripture to them≈øelves and others.
Que≈øt. But how is ≈øuch Interpretation con≈øi≈øtent with the Apo≈øtles ≈øo great A≈ø≈øertion, That Scripture is not of any Private Interpretation?

An≈øw. 2. Such Interpretation as may be Private in regard of its Derivation of any Doctrine from ≈øuch or ≈øuch a particular Place of Scripture, yet keeping it ≈øelf to the Analogy of Scripture, in the plain and undoubted Sen≈øe in other

Yea, even in things controverted between Holy, Wi≈øe, and Good Men, in Interpreting Scri ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ure, each part of the Controver≈øie, when both cannot be reconciled in their Sen≈øe, yet ≈øupports and makes ≈øtronger to their Faith ≈øome grand, evident Principles of Divine and Publick Truth, in which both Sides meet, and are firmly united, and to which each reconcile their own Opinions, wherein they

Que≈øt. All this that hath been de≈øcribed, I confe≈øs, agrees with ≈øo Publick and Catholick a Record as Scripture is: A Record, wherein every one that comes to it, may ≈øearch his own Intere≈øt and Concern in it, and improve it to the utmo≈øt: A Record that offers and expo≈øes it ≈øelf to be under≈øtood and clo≈øely inquired into by all. An≈øw. Herein it is ≈øecure; 1. That Scripture is not of any Interpretation, but its own native Sen≈øe: It is not under the Power of any other: It ≈øtands free, and clear, far above all Interpretation of Men, to be con≈øidered by any one in it ≈øelf, and not under ≈øuch Interpretation. 2. An≈øw. All Interpretation that brings no Credentials from evident Scripture-≈øen≈øe, nor from Heaven, of immediate In≈øpiration, much more if Fal≈øe, or Mean, and impo≈ø≈øible to be ≈øo derived, and yet would impale and inclo≈øe Scripture within it ≈øelf, and impo≈øe it ≈øelf upon the Con≈øciences and Judgments of others, and ≈øo bring them under Bondage: That which forbids Men to Interpret for them≈øelves, though with utmo≈øt Indu≈øtry, and all the A≈ø≈øi≈øtance they can u≈øe, and the Implorings of Divine A≈ø≈øi≈øtance: That which gives out Private Oracles at plea≈øure, and too often mo≈øt Fal≈øe ones, as if they were Scripture, and for its own Private ≈øake would lock Scripture from the po≈ø≈øibility of being Interpreted even by it ≈øelf, ≈øeque≈øtring it into an unknown Tongue, from great Multitudes of all Nations profe≈ø≈øing Je≈øus Chri≈øt. An≈øw. 1. Scripture it ≈øelf is ≈øuch an Infallible Interpreter, it being in all things nece≈ø≈øary to Salvation both clear and certain, to all but the ≈øelf‚ñ™condemned Heretick, or Ignorant.

An≈øw. It is not for us to know the Times and Sea≈øons, which the Father hath put in his own power: But, mo≈øt probably, at the time of fulfilling the great Prophe≈øies of the New Te≈øtament, there ≈øhall be ≈øuch ex ‚Ä¢ raordinary Effu≈øions of the Divine Spirit, as ≈øhall expedite all Doubt, and make every thing clear, the Knowledge of which is not re≈øerved for Heaven, to adorn the Ab≈øolute State of Perfection there.

Que≈øt. Let us now hear the Conclu≈øion of this whole Matter.
An≈øw. It re≈øts in the≈øe two things.

1. That the Evidences of the Divine Pre≈øence in the Scriptures, and all the principal Branches thereof, are as clear and certain, and do ≈øatiate the Soul and its Faculties, inlightned by the general Influences of the Divine Spirit, much more by its ≈øanctifying Efficacy, even as the cleare≈øt Notions we have of Things do, and much above them: And that the≈øe Evidences are the ≈øame in the Original Scriptures, and in the Tran≈ølations, for that they are indeed All Original, and not capable of any Tran≈ølation, but make even Tran≈ølation an Original.

That as Scripture is ≈øuch a Contexture, and makes up ≈øuch a Book, God, the ≈øupreme Governour of the Church, and of the World in general, hath always, and does always take care of its pre≈øervation‚ñ™ from ≈øuch Corruptions as would injure tho≈øe Evidences of Divine In≈øpiration he hath ingraven upon it, not only upon the Sub≈øtance, but upon the very Contexture; and the very ≈øame care he hath taken for the Conveyance of it, by agreeable Tran≈ølations, to the ≈øeveral Nations in their own Tongue, to whom he hath vouch≈øafed the Scriptures them≈øelves, or the Doctrine of them.

An≈øw. Hereby there was at once a Preparation of tho≈øe Scriptures to the mo≈øt Publick Notice, an A≈ø≈øurance of the true Import of the Hebrew Tongue, and an authori≈øed Tran≈ølation: And in the ≈øame ≈øo known Greek Language, wherein are repo≈øed ≈øuch Trea≈øures of all Literature, is added that mo≈øt Sacred Roll of the New Te≈øtament.

div.head: CAP. VIII. Of Tradition and Antiquity.
div.p: Que≈øt. BY what hath been ≈øaid, Scripture and its Interpretation appear guarded by their own Divinene≈øs, again≈øt all Private and Counterfeit, as by Cherubims, and a Flaming Sword turning every way. But hath there been no Stratagem of the Adver≈øary to undermine Divine Catholick Religion, and the Authority of Scripture, the Publick Record of Religion, with its Publick Interpretation; and yet that all the≈øe ≈øhould ≈øeem ≈øtill to re≈øt firm upon their own Ba≈øe?

An≈øw. The great Enemy of God and Truth hath been wanting in no Artifice, and therefore hath fallen upon that very Method inquired of; that what could not be atchieved by denying Scripture, by bringing in Fal≈øe Scripture, or Private Interpretation, mon≈øtrous to the Text, (all ≈øuch gro≈øs Frauds being in ≈øome Times and Places expo≈øed and exploded) might be more ≈øucce≈øsfully attempted and effected, by yoaking Tradition with Scripture, a Private Incertain
Oracle with a Publick and Certain one, and ≈øo avowed to be by the Traditioni≈øts them≈øelves.
Que≈øt. What is Tradition?
An≈øw. The≈øe four things concur to the making up Tradition.

1. That from the Divine Authority of Scriptures, and the True Religion of them, which (as hath been ≈øaid) it acknowledges, it borrows not only Countenance, but Occa≈øion, and more than that, a ≈øhew of Rea≈øon and Nece≈ø≈øity for it ≈øelf.

2. That it therefore endeavours to tack and joyn it ≈øelf to Scripture, and the Religion of it, as nece≈ø≈øary to compleat and fill it up‚ñ™ or to provide ≈øomething more requi≈øite to that Religion, that Scripture hath not provided for.

3. That it having grown up from no true Root, nor ri≈øen upon any ju≈øt Foundation, it hath ≈øtollen into its Authority and Reverence, by being pa≈ø≈øed from Hand to Hand ≈øo long, that its Elderline≈øs looks like a Patent for that Authority and Reverence: And its Original (≈øome Injudicious Devotion, at the be≈øt) not being ea≈øie to be trac'd, it comes to be ≈øuppo≈øed, or rather ≈øuper≈øtitiou≈øly to be ≈øu≈øpected to be Divine; and at length, like a long-told Lie, a≈ø≈øuming to be Truth, it takes upon it ≈øelf to be Divine, and to cur≈øe all tho≈øe that derogate from it.

4. That having thus rivetted it ≈øelf, it by degrees, like Pharaoh's Lean Kine, eats out the generous and rich Sen≈øe of Scripture, and devours the Authority of it, and yet it ≈øelf remains a jejune and ≈øtarv'd Super≈øtition.
