An≈øw. They that have, under the True Religion, ≈øet up ≈øome private Diana of Profit, Honour, or Worldly Advantage, and cannot maintain it by that True Religion, they eke out therefore with Private Tradition what may ≈øupport it.
Que≈øt. What Antidote is there again≈øt the Mi≈øchief of Tradition?

An≈øw. To cleave with full purpo≈øe and re≈øolution of Heart and Soul to the Word of God, and to that only; to have no Religion, nor any thing in Religion, but what is enjoyned and recommended by Divine Authority, in that Ble≈ø≈øed Word of God; and this is indeed to be of the truly Catholick, Apo≈øtolick, and Publick Religion.
Que≈øt. But is the Sen≈øe that hath now been given of Tradition, the be≈øt Sen≈øe of it in Scripture-u≈øe?

An≈øw. No, it is not; and the Con≈øideration of a better Sen≈øe will much clear to us the Nature of Tradition. When therefore our Saviour di≈øcour≈øed of the Commandments of Men, delivered down from Hand to Hand, ≈øub≈øi≈øting only upon the Private Authority of the Elders, not founded on the written Canon of the Old Te≈øtament, at that time the only Rule of Faith, Wor≈øhip, and Practice, he always names Tradition in the ill Sen≈øe already given: But when the Doctrine and Rules of the New Te≈øtament, in tho≈øe grand Points, were ju≈øt breathing from the Holy Spirit, and not yet fixed in that abiding Canon, Tradition is ≈øo long accepted in a good Sen≈øe. The Hi≈øtory of the Things done by our Saviour, though mo≈øt ≈øurely believed, Luc. 1. 1. was fir≈øt but delivered or tradition'd by Word of Mouth, but afterwards written, that the certainty of them might be more fully known to tho≈øe that had been before Catechiz'd in them by Oral Tradition. But yet all the≈øe, though they were Trad ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ons delivered by tho≈øe that were Commi≈ø≈øioned immediately by the Holy Gho≈øt, and were them≈øelves Eye witn ‚Ä¢ ≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , and Earwitne≈ø≈øes of mo≈øt Things they gave in T ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ dition, were yet not ≈øealed ≈øo ≈øure as the more ≈øure Word of Prophe≈øie, becau≈øe they were not yet written by Divine In≈øpiration,
though given out by it, nor generally received and a≈ø≈øured, as ≈øo written, till the due time of Trial by former Scripture had pa≈ø≈øed upon them. The fir≈øt Chri≈øtians did therefore well to take heed to that former Scripture, till they had the full Day of the Go≈øpel, as hath been before ≈øpoken.

If Tradition then was not ≈øo ≈øure in the fir≈øt and truly pure Times of it, how much le≈øs would it have been ≈øure afterwards, if it had continued in Tradition? All therefore of Doctrine in the New Te≈øtament was fir≈øt prepared by Tradition, laid in and proved by the Scriptures of the Old Te≈øtament, either by direct Con≈øequence, or by Interpretation from immediate Revelation, demon≈øtrated, as the Fir≈øt giving of Scripture always was, by Miracles; and ≈øo all at once, and once for all, con≈øigned over to the Po≈øterity of Chri≈øtians by Divinely In≈øpired Writings, ≈øo a≈ø≈øured, ≈øo confirmed, as to leave no place for Tradition o ‚Ä¢ the Be≈øt ≈øen≈øe: There remains therefore nothing for Tradition now, but its Ill ≈øen≈øe.

Que≈øt. Why might not True Religion continue in Tradition, committed all along to Faithful Men, even as it did in ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e Cu≈øtody of the Apo≈øtles, and ≈øuch Faithful Per≈øons as they committed it to?

An≈øw. Even in the time of the Apo≈øtles it was tru≈øted no longer to Tradition, than it mu≈øt needs; for the Apo≈øtle John, the Survivor of them, clo≈øed the Canon of the New Te≈øtament, that was drawn apace into Writing all along: But at that time there was ≈øuch a continual immediate Energy or Efficacy of the Holy Spirit, that Truth mov'd every way, like Lightning, and both by its direct and ≈øtraight forward Motion in Doctrine, and its rever≈øe ≈øtrokes in the Conviction of all Fal≈øhood, Errour was bla≈øted every way: But when this Extraordinary Appearance cea≈øed, there was then no ≈øafety for Truth, but in an unchangeable Written Word, that was in ≈øuch an extraordinary Sea≈øon
of Miracles and immediate Revelation, ≈øetled and e≈øtabli≈øhed, under ≈øo great a Supervi≈øal, in the mid≈øt of ≈øo many Witne≈ø≈øes of all things, by their Eyes and Ears; and it being once written, and always ≈øo ≈øecured by Divine Providence, as hath been repre≈øented, it always ≈øpeaks the ≈øame Things, in the ≈øame Words it fir≈øt did.
Que≈øt. Why might not Divine Truth be committed, ≈øome more Fundamental Parts to Writing, and ≈øome, according to variety of Occa≈øion, to Tradition?

An≈øw. God, to whom all Futurity is pre≈øent, who fore≈øaw all that was nece≈ø≈øary to be written, before he had done writing cannot be ≈øuppo≈øed to commit his Will in part to Writing, and that upon great Rea≈øons; and the ≈øame Rea≈øons notwith≈øtanding, to leave a con≈øiderable part, or ≈øo much as any one Branch obligatory upon the Con≈øcience, to Parol-Tradition: For, if he that offends in one Point is guilty of all, there needs the ≈øame Authority, and as well a≈ø≈øured, for one Point of Faith and Obedience, as for all the re≈øt.

2. It is unconceivable, what End Tradition, uncon≈øign'd by Scripture, can ≈øerve, that Scripture does not more fully and effectually take care for. Publick Religion re≈øerves nothing to be a Cabal for Private Intere≈øt, within a clo≈øe Cabinet or Conclave.

3. Whatever is ≈øuppo≈øed to be entru≈øted to Tradition, mu≈øt either be the very ≈øame we have in Scripture, and then Tradition is needle≈øs and ≈øuperfluous; for we have it in Scripture, if we duly exerci≈øe our ≈øelves in it: or it is more than Scripture hath declared, and yet ≈øuppo≈øed to be of equal Authority with Scripture; and then it mu≈øt be a Motionary and Itinerant Word of God: But where are the daily and continual Seals and Credentials Divine Tradition had, and in a con≈øtant fre≈øh Motion with it, as it moves; for ≈øo it had need be, in ≈øo fluid a Thing as Tradition, if it would pretend to be Sacred; and ≈øo
Divinely In≈øpired Tradition had, while it continued in Tradition: But what Rea≈øon can be given, Tradition, as we now ≈øpeak of it, was not incorporated into Scripture, as was argued before? Or that in ≈øo long a Cour≈øe of Time it hath not been enroll'd into Scripture, as the Doctrine of the Prophets and Apo≈øtles ≈øtill was? Seeing, if it had all things el≈øe, it cannot but want the Benefit of the Divine Contexture and Conveyance that Scripture hath, in Words cho≈øen, and put together by In≈øpiration, and the ready, ea≈øie, and certain Acce≈øs to it by all: For all are equally concerned in it. But how can it be, but there mu≈øt be Tradition, ≈øeeing there were ≈øo many Things ≈øpoken and done, more than the Scripture contains, or the World it ≈øelf could contain, if they were all written? As for all that Chri≈øt did and ≈øpake, or that the Apo≈øtles ≈øpake or did by Infallible Guidance, and Immediate A≈ø≈øi≈øtance, if it be not written, a Veil is drawn over it, and a Cloud hath received it out of our ≈øight: It is a ≈øecret thing, that belongs not to us, but is ≈øealed up from us, like the things which the Thunders uttered in the Revelation.

All too fierce Di≈øputes about them are therefore rai≈øed only by Sathan, the Enemy of Light and Truth, to no other purpo≈øe than that about the Body of Mo≈øes, that is, to found an occa≈øion of Super≈øtition, and ≈øilently to whi≈øper, Scripture is not ≈øufficient. And yet we ≈øee with what an eager Zeal Men are ≈øet upon ≈øuch Re≈øearches, not ≈øatisfied with the Proportion of Manna allowed by God; but even as the I≈øraelites, that gathered much, had nothing over; ≈øo may it be truly ≈øaid of tho≈øe that would abound beyond Scripture, in that which pertains to the true guidance of Con≈øcience, That they have nothing over, and what they will needs keep, as ≈øuch, corrupts.
Que≈øt. Is there Rea≈øon ≈øufficient to ≈øupport this Sentiment?

An≈øw. This great Rea≈øon: If we had undoubted, but not in≈øpired Hi≈øtory of that Time, it could not be like the Evangeli≈øtick Hi≈øtory, or the Actes of the Apo≈øtles to us; we ≈øhould in ≈øome things want the Application and Direction to our u≈øe, dictated by Divine Wi≈ødom; in others, the

Now becau≈øe our Con≈øciences would be apt to be drawn into ≈øubjection to things of ≈øo great Reputation, and yet there would be no Divine Authority to draw them, nor Infallible Authority to ≈øupport them, in which Ca≈øes it is the Ab≈øolute Will of God they ≈øhould not be in ≈øubjection, God hath therefore in his Providence left that time ≈øo much in the dark, that we may tru≈øt in his written Word only.

For ≈øeparate Immediate Divine Pre≈øence from the Prophets and Apo≈øtles them≈øelves, and there remains nothing at the highe≈øt, but the Wi≈ødom and Prudence of Under≈øtanding, and Good Men, applying General Rules to particular Ca≈øes, Times, Places, and Events as they for that time could be≈øt judge, and yet be≈øides the variation of Circum≈øtances in every Age, they them≈øelves were as Men, ≈øubject to mi≈øtakes, as Nathan about David's building the Temple, as Paul a≈ø≈øaying to go into Bithynia; to like Pa≈ø≈øions with other Men, as in the Contention betwixt Paul and Barnabas; to like Temptations, as in the Mi≈øcarriage of Peter before referred to: All they did and ≈øaid, not ≈øhining with immediate Light from Heaven, mu≈øt be tried in the Light of what them≈øelves, together with all the other Penmen of Scripture, had written. But it ≈øtill remains, There might be ≈øome things that were not ≈øo ≈øit for vulgar Knowledge, and ≈øo were Secreted into Tradition apart from Scripture, and that Tradition depo≈øited with Tru≈øty Men, who ≈øhould ≈øucce≈ø≈øively ≈øo depo≈øite it, that it might at convenient Sea≈øons be brought forth, as Goliah's Sword from behind the Ephod.

An≈øw. None like it indeed, to ≈øerve a purpo≈øe: But to ≈øatisfie Rea≈øon and Con≈øcience, nothing ≈øo improper. For, fir≈øt, let the≈øe Traditionaries give clear Expo≈øitions, and ≈øuch as are worthy to be acquie≈øced in, of the Prophetick, or otherwi≈øe Dark Places of Scripture. But the things Tradition is imploy'd indeed in, are quite of another Nature; either the Prelation of Men in Church-Office and Dignity, or ≈øome Rites of Wor≈øhip, that ≈øhould change Devotion into Super≈øtition, or lull it into Ignorance; or ≈øome Canons, that turn Religion into Trade, or Doctrines ≈øuited to that End; or, which ≈øerves to all ≈øuch purpo≈øes, a Tradition to call back all Scripture out of the Written Word into Oral Tradition, by locking it up in a Tongue unknown to the generality of Chri≈øtians. And yet if there were any ≈øeemingly Purer, or more Contemplational Traditions, ≈øeeing they are not inrolled into Scripture, they mu≈øt, as hath been ≈øaid, give ≈øuch Evidences of them≈øelves, as Divine Revelation hath, or be, at their highe≈øt, but Enthu≈øia≈øm and Fanatici≈øm.

Que≈øt. But what E≈øteem is to be had of the Writings and Iran≈øactions of the Ancients, whom we call Fathers, Doctors of the Church, Men of eminent Holine≈øs, great Abilities, Confe≈ø≈øors, and Martyrs of Chri≈øtianity?

An≈øw. It may be ea≈øily judg'd, by what hath been ≈øaid already, that they mu≈øt be brought to Scripture, laid at its Feet, and ≈øubmitted to its Acceptance, whether according to its true Sen≈øe, or not: For, if the Apo≈øtles, when the Holy Spirit was not upon them, could not exceed Humane, how much le≈øs can any of a lower Cla≈øs pretend? The Fathers therefore had ≈øo great an Awe of Scripture, that they did not a≈ø≈øume any thing to them≈øelves or their Writings, or yield any thing to the Per≈øons or Writings of

Que≈øt. But the nearne≈øs of the≈øe Fathers to the Days of Chri≈øt and the Apo≈øtles, mu≈øt needs enable them, either from what they them≈øelves received warm from their Lips, or from what they had from others, not quite cold, to know the Apo≈øtles Doctrine, Di≈øcipline, Manner of Life, Purpo≈øe, their Sen≈øe of the Scope and Meaning of tho≈øe Things wherein they were Divinely In≈øpired, and ≈øo to deliver it to After-ages.

An≈øw. Whatever they have ≈øpoken, or written, giving us more light and advantage to under≈øtand, and behold Scripture in its own Light, ought from them, or from any other, to be accepted with great regard; but if it do not thus, it cannot be accepted, even from the Writers of Scriptures them≈øelves upon a ≈øingle, or divided Authority: They were ≈øo bounded by the very Things, and Words, they them≈øelves had once ≈øpoken and written by the Holy-Gho≈øt, that all the deference to their knowledge in Divine Things above others, was to be made rea≈øonable in the cleare≈øt Expounding what them≈øelves and others had written by Divine In≈øpiration, and to be di≈øcerned in the very Writings them≈øelves, and not to be drawn oracularly out of their Brea≈øts, when the Evidences of Divine In≈øpiration were not upon them: For he that is Spiritual, i. e. that God vouch≈øafes In≈øpiration to, or pretends to it, mu≈øt acknowledge all that is either truly written, or ≈øpoken by the ≈øame In≈øpiration, to be the Commandments of the Lord, 1 Cor. 14. 37.

And as for the newne≈øs, fre≈øhne≈øs, and life of Truth given by Divine Revelation, God graciou≈øly providing it ≈øhould remain, as Revelation left it, and the Evidences it hath done ≈øo, appearing with it; it is the ≈øame in all Ages; Divine never lo≈øes of its life, nor abates of its vigor; what it was ≈øo many Ages ago, that it abides now; what the Holy-Gho≈øt ≈øpoke ≈øo many Ages ago, that

Que≈øt. But ≈øtill the Gifts and Endowments of tho≈øe Eminent Men, with all the Light, Truth, Grace, Learning and Rea≈øon, they ≈øhine to us with, ought to be e≈øteemed and improved?

Yes doubtle≈øs: For what≈øoever Things are true, what≈øoever things are pure, are of Virtue, and de≈øerved prai≈øe, they are Publick, and of God, wherever they are found: And whatever there is in the≈øe Elders, in their nearne≈øs to the Fir≈øt Times, their Holine≈øs, their Sufferings, their great Learning, their Encounters of Pagani≈øm, their Apologies for Chri≈øtianity, their Heavenline≈øs, their Contempt of this World, all is a Donation, and a Grace of God by them to his Church, and Mankind in general.

An≈øw. No doubt there does, both to Chri≈øtianity in particular, and to all Religion, Virtue and Goodne≈øs in general: But yet neither their Writings, nor Practices can in any wi≈øe become Scripture to us; they all lead to Scripture, and ought to do ≈øo; they are all to be ≈øeen, and reflected in Scripture Light, and from thence they receive their lu≈øtre: For though they are a Subordinate Te≈øtimony, as hath been ≈øaid, yet Chri≈øtian Religion hath greater Te≈øtimony, and fir≈øt enabled them to give a valuable Te≈øtimony to it ≈øelf, by Communicating ≈øo great knowledge and worth to them: And be≈øides all that hath

An≈øw. It is mo≈øt evident, as hath been already affirmed, they put a greate≈øt difference betwixt the mo≈øt excellent Monuments of Chri≈øtianity, that were but Humane‚ñ™ whether their own, or others, and in≈øpired Pages; el≈øe Clement, Ignatius, and others, might as well have been Canoniz'd by them, as what is from them come down to us for Sacred Canon it ≈øelf; and even as they did, we may ≈øee the great odds betwixt the one and the other; and as we adore God the ≈øupreme Author, ≈øo the Sovereign Pre≈øerver of Scripture, who by Divine Evidences, and by ≈øuperintending Providence, hath divided the bound of Scripture at ≈øo great a remove from all the Writings

How many Humanes ≈øoever meet, they cannot make up Divine, where it was not before; nor can a multitude of Privates con≈øtitute a Publick: Divine and Publick may be declared, but cannot be made ≈øo by ≈øuch Contribution. An≈øw. Give them all the advantages that can be given, and either we mu≈øt ≈øay, they are Infallibly guided, and then we mu≈øt receive their Decrees, as Scripture, and they mu≈øt be atte≈øted to us, as Scripture is atte≈øted; or they are not Infallibly guided, and then their Decrees mu≈øt be tryed, as all Fallibles ought to be, by a Rule ≈øurer than them≈øelves: If even Divine Revelation it ≈øelf was at fir≈øt tryed, and found perfect; nay, if even all that God propo≈øes to us, as from him≈øelf, comes laden with its own proper Evidences, how much more mu≈øt that which is confe≈ø≈øedly humane, be tryed by that which is confe≈ø≈øedly Divine? The great u≈øe of Councils is therefore ≈øo to debate, and bring things to a Re≈øult, by a confluence of Wi≈ødom and Learning, that we may ≈øee Divine Truths in their own Light, in Scripturelight, to hold out which they are but mini≈øterially imploy'd, and not to impo≈øe upon any under the name of Publick; for that alone is Publick, that is Divine: All
Compari≈øon of Privates among them≈øelves, mu≈øt needs be lo≈øt in this Publick, before which the greate≈øt name of Publick, is but as the drop of the Bucket, and the ≈ømall du≈øt of the Ballance: And the union with that true Publick makes the mo≈øt Private a Publick; and Separation from it, the mo≈øt ≈øeemingly Publick, a mo≈øt Idiottal Private.

div.head: CAP. IX. Of the Church-Catholick.
div.p: Que≈øt. SCripture, the Publick Record of Catholick Religion, being thus far E≈øtabli≈øhed and Secured, both by Internal Characters, and External Care of Providence; it ≈øtill remains nece≈ø≈øary, there ≈øhould be ≈øome ≈øtated Ordination of God, for the Actuating this Record to its ≈øeveral Purpo≈øes and Ends.

1. Becau≈øe Divine Revelation having now fini≈øhed its mea≈øures, there cannot be expected tho≈øe immediate motions of Truth, that were vouch≈øafed by God in his extraordinary Pre≈øences, but all is to be deriv'd from, and di≈øplay'd in Scripture.

p.hi: What therefore is that Ordinance of God, in the Ce≈ø≈øation of Immediate Pre≈øence, for the expo≈øing this Record to its univer≈øal notice, and for the applying it daily to its great purpo≈øes, which is the Executing it, as far as it is to be Executed in this World?

div.p: An≈øw. God hath by his extraordinary Mini≈øters, whom he gave his Divine Revelation, and Word, fir≈øt founded the Church, and, according to the Degrees of that Revelation, exalted it to be ≈øerviceable to this great End, and ≈øo to ≈øupply the place of Immediate Pre≈øence.
Que≈øt. What is to be under≈øtood by the Church?

An≈øw. The Church is The Catholick Congregation of Mankind, called to the Faith and Obedience of that Word it ≈øelf; and which being called it ≈øelf, is entru≈øted to call others to the ≈øame Faith, and Obedience, and ≈øo is Govern'd, and Governs according to it, by daily Exerci≈øes in, and according to that Word.
Que≈øt. Why do you give the Church the ≈øtile of a Congregation, are not the Parts of it ≈øo di≈øtant that they cannot be Congregated in the Wor≈øhip of God?

An≈øw. The Twelve Tribes of I≈ørael, (that is, the Church in its ≈øeveral Members) always united, always ready to the In≈øtant ≈øerving God, Day and Night, are beheld and ≈øeen by him, as in a perpetual actual Congregation.

Particular Churches, yea even Particular Per≈øons, truly of the Church, have every one the whole Character, Title, Promi≈øe, and Privilege of the Catholick Church, ≈øo far as they can need or receive them, even as Heaven is Entire Heaven to every ≈øingle Glorified Soul: Every Lively Member of the Church touches the Head and Corner≈øtone,

Que≈øt. How is this Church Congregated?

An≈øw. It was begun and hath always increa≈øed by Particular Per≈øons converted and brought home to God, according to his Word, in ≈øeveral Ages and Succe≈ø≈øions: For the Church, as it is a Church, is not a Society formed by a common Con≈øent of Men, or by their Will, but its ≈øeveral Parts are added by God, ≈øo that it con≈øi≈øts of all that are inwardly and truly of that Catholick Religion in God the Father, and in the Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt, by the Eternal Spirit, all the World over, and in which meet all that have been, are, or ≈øhall be thus converted by the Word of God, as the Church is, and ≈øhall be triumphant in Glory.

An≈øw. It is evidently ≈øo: All true Converts fir≈øt give them≈øelves to God and Chri≈øt, and, by vertue of That, to the Church. The Apo≈øtles were not ≈øollicitous of any other Conjoyning Men to the Church, than what mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily followed upon their receiving the Go≈øpel, and were afraid of their fixing upon them that were but Mini≈øters and Servants: We preach Je≈øus to be the Lord, and our ≈øelves Servants for Je≈øus ≈øake. But all that are truly The Church, are al≈øo truly called, and truly Converts, not only outwardly and vi≈øibly the Church, but inwardly and invi≈øibly ≈øo too, who≈øe prai≈øe is not of Men, but of God. In the mean time, they that are onely of the Vi≈øible Church, have the Means of Grace, and are not thrown out of that Regi≈øter of God's People, till the Final Judgment cuts them off: A very great Benefit in it ≈øelf!
Que≈øt. Is not the Church then ≈øo Catholick, or General, as the Profe≈ø≈øion of the True Religion is?

An≈øw. The Catholickne≈øs of the Church, as hath been often inculcated, is its Union to God and Chri≈øt, and that in ≈øincerity. As to the general Profe≈ø≈øion, though the number of it be as the Sand of the Sea, a Remnant only ≈øhall be ≈øaved: For God will fini≈øh the Account, and cut it ≈øhort in Righteou≈øne≈øs; for a ≈øhort work will the Lord make in the Vi≈øible Church: There ≈øhall be an often eating, or brou≈øing it off, a retrenching of it again and again; it ≈øhall ca≈øt the Leaves of its meer Profe≈ø≈øors, as the Teyletree or Oak, when yet their Sub≈øtance is in them; the Holy Seed are the Sub≈øtance of it, I≈øa. 6. ult. not lo≈øing them, it lo≈øes nothing.
Que≈øt. In what ≈øen≈øe is it then ≈øaid, The Gates of Hell ≈øhall not prevail again≈øt the Church?

An≈øw. It is undoubted, none can fail while they are the Church, while united to Truth, to the God of Truth, to Chri≈øt, the Way, the Truth, and the Life: It is al≈øo certain, from this high Declaration, there always ≈øhall be a Church in the World, ≈øo united, Hades, or Mortality, ≈øhall not prevail over it; and how much farther it a≈ø≈øures the Per≈øeverance
of tho≈øe that are once truly the Church, I leave the thing it ≈øelf to ≈øpeak. It is ≈øaid, They that overcome ar Pillars, that never go out of it; and, They that go out of it, were not of it; for if they had been indeed of it, they would no doubt have continued with it: And how the Church it ≈øelf ≈øhall always continue, if any True Member of it may peri≈øh, is not ea≈øie to conceive.
Que≈øt. How is the Church ordained by God to actuate Scripture, as it is the Record of Catholick Religion?
An≈øw. The Apo≈øtle, in his Noble De≈øcription of the Church, hath laid the Foundations of our In≈øtruction herein, in tho≈øe three Honourable Titles he hath given it:

list.item: 1. That it is the Hou≈øe of the Living God.
2. That it is the Pillar of Truth.
3. That it is the Ground of Truth.

div.p: Que≈øt. Before the Explanation of each of the≈øe Titles, in the fir≈øt place, I de≈øire it may be determined, whether the≈øe things are ≈øpoken of the Catholick, or of a Particular Church, the Particular Church of Ephe≈øus?

An≈øw. Although I have already affirmed, That the Catholick Church differs from a Particular True Church only in the Compa≈øs and Comprehen≈øivene≈øs of it; yet I very willingly repre≈øent it over again in this In≈øtance: The≈øe things are truly applied to the Catholick Church, to the Particular Church of Ephe≈øus, to every Particular Church; nay, it reaches down to every ≈øingle living Member of the Church, ≈øo far, that God makes his abode with him, dwells in him, he is a Pillar in the Hou≈øe of God, the Truth re≈øts and dwells in him, and ≈øhall be with him for ever; ≈øo that he is a Ground of Truth, and hath more of the Church in him, than greater ≈øeeming Portions of it, that erre from the Truth.
Que≈øt. If you plea≈øe now to proceed in the Explanation of the≈øe Titles; and fir≈øt, What is the Importance of the Churches being the Hou≈øe of God, for the actuating the Scripture?

An≈øw. God, the mo≈øt High Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øour and Owner of Heaven and Earth, places his Court, Family, and particular Re≈øidence where he plea≈øes; and he hath cho≈øen the Church to be this to him. This is my Re≈øt, here will I dwell for ever, for I have de≈øired it. Heaven is my Throne, Earth is my Foot≈øtool; where is the Hou≈øe you will build me? To this Man will I look, that trembles at my Word. And where God dwells, there he manife≈øts him≈øelf: As a Ma≈øter of a Family makes known in his Hou≈øe and Family his Nature, Will, Laws, and Government; ≈øo God does in his Church: In Judah is God known, his Name is great in I≈ørael. In his Church he ≈øhews the Light of his Countenance, expects and rewards Services, as a Great Ma≈øter, and makes known his Di≈ølikes and Di≈øplea≈øure. This is brought to pa≈øs in the Church by tho≈øe many Ways that God hath of bringing his Word to any Places or Per≈øons, giving it Reception among them, and then ≈øtirring up his Children and Servants to hear his Voice, to ≈øearch his Mind and Will, and to under≈øtand it; ≈øo that it is as a Voice continually behind them. In his Temple therefore, in his Hou≈øe, every one mu≈øt needs ≈øpeak of his Glory: His Word cannot lie ≈øtill, for all are concerned to meditate, ponder, inquire, and di≈øcour≈øe of it, and are by Supreme Management excited ≈øo to do; and ≈øo much as this Exerci≈øe in his Word is by any means depre≈ø≈øed, ≈øo far God is withdrawn, and the Excellency of the Church-≈øtate lo≈øt. Now of the Church being the Hou≈øe of God, there was this great Type: God dwelt in the Temple at Jeru≈øalem, as in a Palace; there was ≈øuch a Diet of Shewbread, changed every day; of Sacrifices of all ≈øorts; ≈øuch Perfumes of Incen≈øe and Odours, ≈øuch Officers and Servants attending continually, ≈øuch Re≈øorts of the whole Body of the People to the Court of this Great King and Princely Hou≈øholder. Together with this State, runs along in a mighty Stream, Gods ≈øhewing his Word to Jacob,
his Statutes and Judgments to I≈ørael. In the New Te≈øtament, the Pomp and Ceremonial Part is wholly transferred into Spirituality; but Spirituality is not lower, but higher in the Sub≈øtance of all that could be figured by the≈øe things: and the ≈øub≈øtantial part of that State, the Communication of the Word of God, is much exalted in the true Chri≈øtian Church, that the Light of One Day is now as much as the Light of Seven was before. Thus the Church, as the Family of God, cannot but actuate his Word.
Que≈øt. What is the meaning of the Church being the Pillar of Truth? Does the Church ≈øupport Truth?
An≈øw. Not ≈øo; for, it ≈øelf is built upon the Foundation of the Prophets and Apo≈øtles, Je≈øus Chri≈øt him≈øelf being the chief Corner-≈øtone.
Que≈øt. How then is it ≈øaid to be the Pillar of Truth? And of what Importance is that to the Actuating Scripture?

An≈øw. As the Laws and Ordinances of Courts and Governments are publickly fixed, that every one may know and take notice of them; ≈øo the Church in all its Members, but e≈øpecially by Deputed Mini≈øters, giving them≈øelves wholly to it, proclaims, preaches, and makes offer of the mo≈øt Publick Notice of the Word of Truth, within it ≈øelf, that all the Children and Servants of the Family may be continually catechiz'd and built up therein, and Strangers have opportunity to know, if they would apply them≈øelves to it. Thus it is a Famous City ≈øet on an Hill, that cannot be hid; and therefore its Laws, Con≈øtitutions, Manners, cannot but in all rea≈øon be inquired of, by all that do ≈øo much as pa≈øs by it: It is a Candle≈øtick, bearing the lofty Torch of Divine Truth. Of this the Pillars of the Temple at Jeru≈øalem, and the affixing to them the Rolls of Divine Revelation, was an eminent Type, and alluded to by the Apo≈øtle. As therefore from a Prince come forth Edicts, Proclamations, Manife≈øto's, and Declarations, according
to Laws, which are fa≈øtned to Publick Pillars of the Court it ≈øelf, and all open and con≈øpicuous Places of Concour≈øe; ≈øo are there in the Church the mo≈øt advantagious Publications of the Divine Truth and Word, to all, both the Natives and Free-born of the Church it ≈øelf, and Ingenuous Strangers, that would hearken out the mo≈øt Rea≈øonable Propo≈øals of Truth, or whom God is plea≈øed to Naturalize to him≈øelf.
Que≈øt. What is the meaning of the Church being the Ground of Truth? And how does this actuate Scripture?

An≈øw. It means nothing but the Perpetuity and Continuation of Truth with the Church, e≈øtabli≈øhing it ≈øelf by all that Firmne≈øs of Divine Evidence and Rea≈øon, and on tho≈øe very Securities taking Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Church, as the Ark of its Strength, where it ≈øelf, or the God that is Truth it ≈øelf, places the Soles of his Feet, as on his unmovable Foot≈øtool, for ever: Of which the Ark in the Hol ‚Ä¢ e≈øt was a Type, the Foot≈øtool of the Throne of Mercy, the ≈øecure Repo≈øitory of the Tables of the Covenant, the Ark of Te≈øtimony, over which the Shecinah or Glory appeared as inthron'd, attended with Cherubims, and ≈øetting its Feet upon it; the place of my Throne, and the place of the Soles of my Feet, Ezek. 43. 7. For thus the True Church, again≈øt which the Gates of Hell cannot prevail, is the unchangeable Re≈øt of Truth: It adheres to Truth; it buys the Truth, and never ≈øells it; Truth dwells with it for ever: God never ≈øuffers it to apo≈øtatize from Truth; but by the con≈øtant holding of the Judgment, and retaining the Love and Zeal of the Affections of tho≈øe that are indeed his Church, he hath ≈øetled his Word in his Church on Earth, even as it is for ever ≈øettled in Heaven. The Church therefore actuates Scripture, by finding out Rea≈øons, debating, enforcing, defending by all Arguments, that Truth of Scripture, and ≈øo per≈øi≈øting in it for ever.
Que≈øt. Cannot then the Church fail?

An≈øw. It hath been ≈øaid before, the True Church cannot fail: For, the True Church is (as hath been de≈øcribed) the Hou≈øe of God, the Pillar and Ground of Truth; and that which is ≈øo, cannot fail, and God will have ≈øuch a Church always in the World. If any Per≈øon, City, or Nation, that ≈øeem to have been the Church, have this Light eclip≈øed, the ‚Ä¢ an ‚Ä¢ le≈øtick removes; for it is only a Candle≈øtick for the ≈øake of the Light: and the Pillar it ≈øelf ≈øhakes and falls, if the Records fixed to it are taken away: and the Palace and Court remove with the Prince, who is always with his Truth, and the lively Motion of it. So much Truth therefore, and active Di≈øplay of it, ≈øo much a Church, in any Place; and the Truth removing, or lying dead, the Church removes al≈øo, or is ready to die in that Place.
Que≈øt. But is there no higher Sen≈øe of the Church being the Pillar and Ground of Truth?

An≈øw. No other, but what ari≈øes from the mo≈øt intimate and in≈øeparable Union betwixt the Church and Truth; Truth taking an undefailable po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Church: ≈øo that whereever Truth, in that Fulne≈øs as to lead to Life and Happine≈øs, is, there is the Church, and no where el≈øe. The True Church then may be ≈øtiled a Pillar and Ground of Truth in the highe≈øt Sen≈øe, if rightly under≈øtood; that is, Truth it ≈øelf, that is the unmovable Pillar and everla≈øting Foundation, hath ≈øo clo≈øely banded the Church with it ≈øelf, that it is One Pillar and Foundation with it. Thus the Church may be both the Building; and the Rock and Foundation, to ≈øucceeding Parts and Members of the Church: The Building, as it ≈øelf re≈øts upon the Pillar and Foundation of Truth; el≈øe it can't be the Church: The Pillar and Foundation of Truth, to the ≈øtill ≈øucceeding and ri≈øing Church, as it is One with Truth it ≈øelf, to which every True Member fir≈øt comes and unites, and therein to the Church; even as every Degree of Building is a Foundation and Support to the ≈øtill growing Building, not in
it ≈øelf, but as it is ≈øurely cemented to the Foundation, regulated by it, and partakes its Strength: Yet if it ≈øwerve never ≈øo little from the Foundation, it is pre≈øently a Deformity; and the more it ≈øwerves, the greater danger of the Ruine of it ≈øelf, and all that re≈øts upon it.

Que≈øt. May not this help to explain that ≈øo much di≈øputed Expre≈ø≈øion of our Saviour, Thou art Peter, and upon this Rock I will build my Church, and the Gates of Hell ≈øhall not preval again≈øt it?

An≈øw. I ≈øhall be glad if it may give any Light to it, and hope it may: For the Apo≈øtle Peter making that Confe≈ø≈øion of the Divinity of Chri≈øt, not ≈øingular, but repre≈øenting the whole Body of Apo≈øtles and Chri≈øtians, and being po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed with and by that Truth he confe≈øs'd, was both part of the Building upon that Rock, and, as united with that Rock, he became Rock it ≈øelf, upon which ≈øucceeeding Chri≈øtians were to be built. The Prophets and Apo≈øtles are in this Sen≈øe Foundations, and the Twelve Apo≈øtles Twelve Foundations, Chri≈øt him≈øelf being the Corner-≈øtone, in whom alone the whole Building, even the Apo≈øtolick Foundation it ≈øelf, ri≈øes, in a ≈øtrict and proper Sen≈øe.
Que≈øt. Is there not a good Security then in joyning our ≈øelves to the Church, to tho≈øe that have been in the Building before us?

An≈øw. No otherwi≈øe than as we joyn our ≈øelves, by their Mini≈øtry, to that Foundation it ≈øelf, which always lies ≈øure, upon which they them≈øelves mu≈øt alone re≈øt, if the True Church. For, by placing our ≈øelves not upon them, but upon that Common Foundation, we are adju≈øted to the whole Building that was before us, that lies regular with that Foundation, by the Care of him who is both the Foundation, Corner-≈øtone, and is al≈øo he that built all things, even God in Chri≈øt
Que≈øt. We mu≈øt then ≈øeek to find the Truth by it ≈øelf, and then the Church by that Truth; and not the Church by it ≈øelf, and then the Truth by the Church?

An≈øw. Very true: For God hath ≈øo in his Infinite Wi≈ødom e≈øtabli≈øh'd the very Nature of Things. Truth can give many A≈ø≈øurances of it ≈øelf to us by it ≈øelf, ≈øo ≈øuited to our Faculties: The Church can give us none, but by its agreement with Truth, revealed in the Word of God. We could not have known ≈øuch a Congregation as the Church at all to be, much le≈øs which it is, but by that Word manife≈øting it ≈øelf in our Con≈øciences, and ≈øo di≈øtingui≈øhing to us the True Church among the many A≈ø≈øociations in the World, each calling to us, as having the be≈øt Religion among them≈øelves. Even the True Apo≈øtles them≈øelves could be known to be ≈øo, and Fal≈øe Apo≈øtles tried and found Liars, no other way, but by this Truth, view'd, and con≈øidered ≈øingly, and di≈øtinctly by it ≈øelf.
Que≈øt. But when we have found the Church by the Truth, may we not then deliver up our ≈øelves wholly to the Church, as ≈øo united to Truth?

An≈øw. No, by no means: We can never ≈øo deliver up our ≈øelves; nor will the True Church de≈øire any ≈øuch thing of us, ≈øeeing its Office is not to hold out it ≈øelf, but the Word of Truth; and in doing any thing el≈øe, it acts not as a Church, but as any other ordinary Society; and on no other Terms can we have to do with it: For the very Attempt to hold out, as a Church, any Laws of its own, ought to enter us into a Jealou≈øie whether it be the True Church, which is, as a Church, the Pillar and Re≈øt of Divine Truth only.
Que≈øt. What Rea≈øon is there of ≈øuch a Jealou≈øie, when once we have found it a Church, by the Truth it holds out?
An≈øw. Becau≈øe a Church, that hath been a True Church, may ≈øeveral ways decline from its State.
Que≈øt. How then can it he ≈øaid, The Gates of Hell ≈øhall not prevail again≈øt it?

An≈øw. That Prophetick Promi≈øe does not ≈øecure this or that Particular Church, but that there ≈øhall be a Seed of the Church in the World, with which the Covenant of God is Eternal: My Word ≈øhall not depart out of thy Mouth. nor out of the Mouth of thy Seed, or thy Seed's Seed, for ever.

But it is yet further true, the True Seed, the Holy Seed, the Sub≈øtance of the Church, can never utterly and finally fail in any Particular Member of it; for if it could, it were too great a violation of our Saviour's Truth in that Declaration, The Gates of Hell ≈øhall not prevail again≈øt his Church, or force that Immortal retrograde into Mortality, even that mo≈øt dreadful one of the Second Death, for which a Succe≈ø≈øion of others, and in the ≈øame Danger, is but a faint Salvo, though it go on ≈øo to the End of the World.
Que≈øt. Who are this True Church in every Age and Place?

An≈øw. They which are by True Saving Faith united to Chri≈øt the Son of God, the Rock of Eternity; and being ≈øo founded upon him, are Pillars that never remove, and a Re≈øt of Truth for ever, having been taught, and learnt it, as it is in Je≈øus.
Que≈øt. Who are the Profe≈ø≈øionary Church only?

An≈øw. They that though they may, as Artificial Pillars, give ≈øome Ornament to the Hou≈øe of God, and offer Truth, yet not being indeed united to the Foundation, are movable, and may go out of the Hou≈øe. They are ≈øuch as have not received the Truth in the Love and Obedience of it within them≈øelves, and ≈øo may fall away from it: It cannot be ≈øaid of them, as of the former, The Truth ≈øhall be with them for ever, having made its Edr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ma or Settlement in them.
Que≈øt. How does the Profe≈ø≈øionary Church fall away in the Bulk and Body of its Profe≈ø≈øors, and Profe≈ø≈øion?

An≈øw. The Office of the Church being to Actuate Truth, and only Truth, it may fail, either in abating the Fervours due to Truth, though nothing Fal≈øe or Forreign be admitted, or in receiving Fal≈øhood, or things of a ba≈øer Alloy, for Truth, and wa≈øting tho≈øe Fervours due only to Truth upon them. The one may be called a departing from the true State of a Church; the other, from the State of a True Church: and they u≈øually meet one in another.
Que≈øt. How does this come to pa≈øs?

An≈øw. From the Judgment of God upon the pre≈øent ≈øinful State, permitting things ≈øo to them≈øelves, that in very few In≈øtances it is, but that the Imperfections of Good Men, and the prevailing Corruptions of Profe≈ø≈øionary Chri≈øtians, change the Holy, Lively Activities of the True State of a Church, into Lukewarmne≈øs and Formality, or by admitting Fal≈øhood, and impure Mixtures, into Doctrine, Wor≈øhip, and Di≈øcipline, corrupt the State of the Church, ≈øo that it lo≈øes its Truth.
Que≈øt. What becomes of the Profe≈ø≈øionary Church, when it lo≈øes the True State of a Church?

An≈øw. It is, as the Prophet expre≈ø≈øes a Civil State, or a City that hath lo≈øt its Splendour; It becomes like a burnt Mountain, or extingui≈øh'd Globe of Light: It retains the Form, but lo≈øes the Life and Vigour of a Church, like Ephe≈øus, that lo≈øt its Fir≈øt Love; or Sardis, that had a Name to live, but was dead; or Laodicea, that was neither cold nor hot.
Que≈øt. What becomes of it when it is corrupted, and lo≈øes in its Truth?

An≈øw. It exchanges the Lively Oracles for Forms of Doctrine, and Lifele≈øs Di≈øcour≈øe, not of the High Spirit of Scripture: It deba≈øes pure Wor≈øhip into Ceremonialne≈øs, Super≈øtition, or Idolatry; and the Go≈øpel Rule and Di≈øcipline it ≈øells for a Worldly Politie; and the true Graces of Chri≈øtianity, expre≈ø≈øed in a Holy Conver≈øation, for what is much beneath, or contrary. Sometimes it for≈øakes Truth
in ≈øome Fundamental Article, that it ≈øwells out from the Foundation, in a Breach, ready to fall: And there is one In≈øtance of all the≈øe in the Anti-Church, which will de≈øerve a greater Con≈øideration.
Que≈øt. How does God deal with ≈øuch Churches?

An≈øw. Sometimes ≈øweeps them with the Bee≈øom of De≈øtruction, taking away both the Candle≈øtick and Place of it together, Alienes Both to them and their Religion thru≈øting them out of their whole Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion: Sometimes he ≈øuffers them to continue even for Ages, yet ≈øo that their Candle≈øtick is moved out of its due ≈øtately Po≈øiture, hardly appearing like a Candle≈øtick, and that by the Indignation of God.
Que≈øt. In the≈øe Ca≈øes how does it fare with the True Holy Seed, the Sub≈øtantial Church?

An≈øw. God cha≈øtens them to Repentance, Self-purification, and greater Zeal, in that Ca≈øe of the Churches lo≈øing its Brightne≈øs and Vigour, that they may recover their fir≈øt State and Work, aad ≈øets them on work to retrive Truth lo≈øt, in that other Ca≈øe of the Churches Defection.
Que≈øt. How is it with them, when the very Place and Candle≈øtick are taken away?

An≈øw. They are either fir≈øt removed into the higher State of the Church in Heaven, or driven before into other Parts of the World, by Per≈øecution; or the violence of the Judgment makes no di≈øtinction, but carries them Captive with the re≈øt, though in different Baskets, as the Prophet Jeremy repre≈øents.
Que≈øt. How do they ≈øurvive in the time of the di≈øplac'd and dejected Candle≈øtick?

An≈øw. They are either called out to a Zealous Appearance and Suffering for Truth, or ≈øometimes retired into Corners, like the Seven thou≈øand in I≈ørael, or the Church in the Wilderne≈øs, that they cannot appear like a Church, offering tho≈øe Publick Notices of Divine Truth a Church is de≈øigned for.
Que≈øt. How is a Vi≈øible Profe≈ø≈øion lo≈øt from Particular Per≈øons?

An≈øw. It is too often thrown up by Apo≈øta≈øie or Profanene≈øs, or dwindled into a very Spiritle≈øs Form; but very often a Profe≈ø≈øion without the Power being not incon≈øi≈øtent with the working of Iniquity, it may pa≈øs out of this World like a Lamp burning: but being found to burn only in a ≈ømall Temporary Light, without Oyl in the Ve≈ø≈øel, a Plenitude of Grace in the Heart, ≈øhutting out every Lu≈øt, it becomes a Lamp put out in utter Darkne≈øs.
Que≈øt. What is to be inferred from all this?

An≈øw. That there is no Tru≈øt but in the Lord him≈øelf, the Truth it ≈øelf, by which at all times the Church, that is indeed the Pillar and Ground of Truth, and wherein it is ≈øo, will be known to us; and in uniting to Truth, we are united to That.

Que≈øt. There remains one thing yet to be under≈øtood in the De≈øcription of the Church, which is, its Power of Governing, even as it is Governed by the Word of God: ∆≤nder what Notions, I be≈øeech you, is that Government expre≈ø≈øed in Scripture?
An≈øw. That Power is by our Saviour repre≈øented under the Mataphor of Keys; and the U≈øe of tho≈øe Keys, in opening and ≈øhutting, or in Binding and Lo≈øing.
Que≈øt. What is the meaning hereof?

An≈øw. The meaning is plainly this; When the Church of Chri≈øt hath by the Key of Knowledge inquir'd into all the Divine and Heavenly Doctrine of the Go≈øpel and Word of God, it hath in and according to that Word, and only ≈øo, a Power of Application of that Doctrine to Particular Ca≈øes, binding Men under the Sen≈øe of Guilt, and fear of Damnation, in ≈øuch or ≈øuch Sins, and an impenitent Continuance in them; or of Ab≈øolving, and a≈ø≈øuring Men of the Divine Favour and Acceptance, in a holy cour≈øe
of Life, and Obedience to God, and of Pardon upon Repentance, after Falls into Sin, and Di≈øobedience; and ≈øo of Declaring and Pronouncing upon Men, as to their pre≈øent State in the Church, by Excommunication, or Ab≈øolution; all the≈øe are the Power of Binding and Loo≈øing; according to what our Saviour ≈øpeaks in parallel Words, Who≈øe Sins you remit, they are remitted; who≈øe Sins you retain, they are retained; meaning ≈øtill according to his Word, the Pole-Star by which they are to direct all their Motions, who claim any ≈øuch Power: For, only where it is declard according to the Word, is it, that what is bound on Earth, is al≈øo bound in Heaven; and what is loo≈øed on Earth, is loo≈øed in Heaven; there being an Invariable Agreement between what is Publi≈øhed from Heaven, in the Word of God, concerning the State and Actions of Men on Earth, and the Tran≈øactions in Heaven, in relation to them. He then that pronounces agreeably with that word, pronounces as Heaven does and will pronounce; Heaven binds what he binds, and loo≈øes what he loo≈øes, becau≈øe he ≈øpeaks the Voice of Heaven in both Ca≈øes.

But that there ≈øhould be any Binding or Loo≈øing, except in the Power of this Word, and according to it, in its Vertue, in its Truth, nothing can be more contrary to the Ends, to the Glory, to the Soveraignty of Chri≈øt. To bind any ≈øingle Chri≈øtian by Excommunication, and not according to this Word, is as much a Brutum Fulmen, a Thunder to no purpo≈øe, a cau≈øele≈øs Cur≈øe, that ≈øhall not come, as for the Pope to Excommunicate whole Prote≈øtant Churches.
Que≈øt. What is a Particular Church?

An≈øw. It is the Catholick Church in a Neighbourhood, or number of Chri≈øtians Communicating one with another ordinarily; even as the whole Cotholick Church, would, if it were po≈ø≈øible, Communicate with it ≈øelf, in the Ordinances, and Wor≈øhip of Chri≈øt, exactly according the to Rules of his Word; wherein this is the di≈øtingui≈øhing Character
of the True Church, that its Communion is not with it ≈øelf primarily, but its Communion is ≈øo with it ≈øelf, as to be with the Father, and his Son Je≈øus Chri≈øt principally, as the Fountain-Head, Center and Rule of the Communion, and therein it holds out, and invites to its Communion.

div.head: CAP. X. Of the Officers appointed by Chri≈øt in his Church.
div.p: Que≈øt. CAn there be either an Orderly, or an Effectual Actuation of the Truth, by the Church as a Congregation, without di≈øtinct and ≈øeparate Offices and Officers that may attend continually on this very thing?

An≈øw. It is impo≈øible; for, an A≈ø≈øembly without Order, would cea≈øe to be an A≈ø≈øembly, and fall into a Confu≈øion, or Rude Multitude. All Wi≈øe and Prudent A≈ø≈øemblies have always had Elders to pre≈øide over them; and our Lord hath ordained ≈øuch to moderate throughout his Congregation or Church, to conduct all the Publick Services of Religion: For all things therein are actually admini≈øtred by the Mini≈øters of Chri≈øt, the Noble≈øt Organical Parts of the Church, like tho≈øe Sen≈øes that attend upon the Under≈øtanding mo≈øt immediately; Seeing Eyes, and Hearing Ears; ≈øo the≈øe upon the Word of Chri≈øt. And that they may be mo≈øt fitted, ingaged, and provoked hereunto, they are, even according to the very Laws of Nature, ≈øeparated to their Offices, and unto all Preparations for them, by Reading and Meditation, as to their Proper Calling and Bu≈øine≈øs of Life, ≈øeeing they do not pretend to Immediate and Extraordinary Inablements, or Excitations to their Service.
Que≈øt. What Titles or Characters does the New Te≈øtament place upon the≈øe Officers?

An≈øw. Tho≈øe that we have e≈øpecial Re≈øpect to (for in the Deacons, if ≈øtrictly taken, we are le≈øs concerned) receive
Denominations either from their Work and Service, or from that Honour and E≈øtimation due to the Faithful Di≈øcharge of ≈øuch a Service. From their Work they are ≈øtiled Apo≈øtles, Evangeli≈øts, Pa≈øtors, Teachers, Mini≈øters, Servants of God and Chri≈øt, and in a ju≈øt ≈øen≈øe, of the Church al≈øo. From the E≈øtimation and Honour due to the Di≈øcharge of their Work, and the Authority it ought to carry in the Hearts and Con≈øciences of Chri≈øtians, they are ≈øtyled Bi≈øhops, Elders, Rulers, Guides, and En≈øamples, as al≈øo, Emba≈ø≈øadours: And the Work and the Honour do ≈øo enclo≈øe one another, that they ought not to be ≈øeparated, and are in their In≈øtitution the Mea≈øure one of another, extending both to Obedience, and Support of them in their Work; and the Titles are ≈øo prepared by the Wi≈ødom of the Holy Gho≈øt, that they ought not to be changed for any other, nor the Scripture Language herein to be altered, for any Words not importing the ≈øame proper Sen≈øe.
Que≈øt. How ≈øhall the True Mini≈øters of Chri≈øt be known, that there may be that Obedience and Submi≈ø≈øion paid to them that is commanded?

An≈øw. There can be no other Means to di≈øcern them, but by the Word of Righteou≈øne≈øs, of which all True Mini≈øters are the Mini≈øters, on account of which alone, Obedience and Submi≈ø≈øion to them is due: Their bringing that Word in its own Life, Evidence, and Power, is their be≈øt Commi≈ø≈øion.
Que≈øt. But how are they mo≈øt orderly en≈øtall'd into ≈øo high a Function?

An≈øw. Chri≈øt as the Head of the Church, hath a≈øcended up on high, and given gifts to Men, and as the Lord of the Harve≈øt takes it upon him, as his Supreme Care, to thru≈øt forth Labourers into his Harve≈øt. The ≈øeveral Congregations of Chri≈øtians, ob≈øerving Mini≈øterial Abilities, and Meetne≈øs to Teach, call out to ≈øuch to help them; and herein, in the Ce≈ø≈øation of Extraordinary Gifts, the Schools of Learning and Religious Education, like the Schools of the Prophets,
do be≈øt prepare; and the Judgment of tho≈øe that have been Pa≈øtors and Teachers before them, does mo≈øt orderly recommend to Choice and Acceptance, in the great Service, ≈øuch as are Scribes, in≈øtructed to the Kingdom of Heaven, and commits to them the Charge of Teaching others: For in this, as in all other Acts, the Elders of the Church are to pre≈øide, with due Re≈øpect to the Congregation.
Que≈øt. Is the Lord Chri≈øt plea≈øed then to act generally by the Elders and Officers of the Church?

An≈øw. Generally and ordinarily he does ≈øo; the Officers are therefore more particularly entru≈øted by Chri≈øt with the Keys, even as the Church in general is. Thus eminently, by the Mini≈øtry of the Apo≈øtles, our Lord founded his Church, and ≈øo edifies and builds it up in After-ages, by Pa≈øtors and Teachers; and when great Defections have prevailed upon it, ≈øummons it to Reformation, by ≈øome rais'd up among tho≈øe Officers, and whom he ≈øends out, as ≈øuch, to reform and recover his Church: Yet ≈øtill all this Power is in and according to his Word, and no other; and ≈øo, that in all things, as much as may be, the Knowledge, Judgment and Approbation of the Church is to be joyn'd in all the Officers do, as having their Intere≈øt in the Keys al≈øo; becau≈øe they have their Intere≈øt in the Word of God, in the Under≈øtanding, Opening and Applying of which to Particular Ca≈øes, the whole Power of the Keys re≈øts. The Apo≈øtles, Elders, and the Brethren, or whole Church, were together plea≈øed, and together joyn'd in that Famous Conciliary Epi≈øtle, Acts 15. 22.
Que≈øt. I de≈øire your more full Explanation of the Publick Offices of the Chri≈øtian Church, and the Power accompanying it?
An≈øw. I will very willingly do as you de≈øire, and begin with the Apo≈øtles.
Que≈øt. Wherein ≈øtood their Power?

An≈øw. It ≈øtood in their Preaching, Acting, Directing, Governing, by that Immediate and Infallible A≈ø≈øi≈øtance of
the Divine Spirit, by which they writ and ≈øealed Scripture, and by which they were ≈øo guarded every way, that they could turn neither to the Right Hand nor to the left, in any thing wherein they exerci≈øed this Power.
Que≈øt. How was this Power Ju≈øtified?

An≈øw. By the Divinene≈øs, ≈øub≈øtantial Goodne≈øs, and Rea≈øonablene≈øs of all their Pre≈øcriptions, propos'd in all the Methods of Rational Di≈øcour≈øe, and manife≈øtation of them≈øelves in Mens Con≈øciences, witne≈øs'd to by the Holy Spirit, and authori≈øed by a Power of Miracles, generally of Beneficence, or doing good; and in ≈øome, but ≈øparing In≈øtances, of infliction of Bodily Pains, or Death.
Que≈øt. Did the Apo≈øtles never err in their Admini≈øtration?

An≈øw. Whenever that Infallible Guidance was not pre≈øent to them, they might err, as was before ob≈øerved in the Apo≈øtle Peter's Mi≈øcarriage, which no doubt was recorded to ≈øhew their Power was not in them≈øelves, but in the Divine Spirit acting by them; that none in After-ages, might pretend to dictate as their Succe≈ø≈øors, having not their Power, and yet requiring Obedience, as if they had it; whereas even the Apo≈øtles them≈øelves might err, and ≈øo lo≈øe their Power, if never ≈øo little de≈øerted by the Holy Spirit: And therefore what they con≈øigned over to After-ages, was winnowed from every thing Humane and Fallible, that both Officers and People might know the one Common Rule, by which one is to Govern, the other, in the Application of it, is to be Governed.
Que≈øt. Who were next to the Apo≈øtles in this Office and Power?

An≈øw. Evangeli≈øts, ≈øuch as were Timothy and Titus, who having a Portion of the Apo≈øtolick Work, to plant and ≈øettle Churches, and Ordinary Officers in them, had al≈øo a Portion of their Power to enable them to it, it being ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary there ≈øhould be ≈øuch, till the General Rule was fully ≈øettled and fixed.
Que≈øt. Were not the Apo≈øtles and Evangeli≈øts above Ordinary Pa≈øtors and Teachers?

An≈øw. They were, in this great Point of Difference, that they had the Word of God by Immediate and Infallible Revelation committed to them, to commit the ≈øame to others, by direction from the ≈øame Spirit, who gave them Di≈øcerning to whom to entru≈øt it, till all things relating to the Kingdom of God in the Church were ≈øealed in the Canon of the New Te≈øtament; el≈øe they owned them≈øelves Compresbyters, as the Apo≈øtle Peter ≈øtiles him≈øelf, A Presbyter with Presbyters.
Que≈øt. From all that hath been ≈øpoken, we are to conclude, That the whole Power in the Church, and in all things pertaining to Religion, is retained in the Word of God.

An≈øw. It is ≈øo: For Chri≈øt in his Word is the only King and Lawgiver of his Church, which Glory he will not give to another: Whatever Power can be ≈øuppo≈øed re≈øident in the whole Church together, is no other than in that Word of Truth publickly offered by it. The Apo≈øtles Power was only the pre≈øence of that Word to them, by the Immediate Revelation, and infallible Guidance of the Holy Spirit, for the Preaching it throughout the World, and thereby founding the Chri≈øtian Church: Such was the ordinary Power of any extraordinary Mini≈øters under them. The and con≈øtant Ruler≈øhip of the Elders of the Church remains unmoveably in the Word, which it is their Office to ≈øpeak.
Que≈øt. Are not tho≈øe we di≈øtingui≈øhingly call Bi≈øhops, Succe≈ø≈øours to the Apo≈øtles, in that Preeminency they had over other Pa≈øtors and Elders?
An≈øw. That Succe≈ø≈øors to the preeminency of the Apo≈øtles may be well e≈øtabli≈øhed, Three things are nece≈ø≈øary,

1. That there be found, and produced Di≈øtinct Commands given in Scripture ‚Ä¢ o the Inferior Mini≈øters of the New Te≈øtament to obey Superior Mini≈øters, or Bi≈øhops; Commands to Chri≈øtians to obey Inferior Mini≈øters, or Ordinary Presbyters, as Inferior Mini≈øters, with re≈øpect to Superior Mini≈øters, and tho≈øe Superior Mini≈øters, as Superiors.
We mu≈øt find the Apo≈øtle di≈øtingui≈øhing, ordinary Presbyters; as Inferior Mini≈øters, with re≈øpect to Superior Mini≈øters; and tho≈øe Superior Mini≈øters, as Superiors; as we find him di≈øtingui≈øhing Civil Magi≈øtrates into the King, as Supreme; and Governors, as tho≈øe that are ≈øent by him.

2. Seeing it is very clear, and apparent, there is nothing more di≈øtant from the De≈øign of the Go≈øpel, than to Con≈øtitute any thing for the ≈øake of making a great Figure, without as great an U≈øe, or End; and that Chri≈øt hath not given Power to his Rulers to Command the very lea≈øt thing, but as Commanded by him≈øelf fir≈øt, for then they would be Lords, which he plainly declares again≈øt, and ab≈øolutely denies to them, and that what they do as Commanded by him, they ≈øhould do ≈øo in Duty and Service to the Supreme Lord, and Subordinately to his Church, as not to be called, or e≈øteem'd Benefactors for their Services; ≈øo that it mu≈øt be evident, what their Superior Service is; it mu≈øt be plainly expre≈ø≈øed in the Word of God, and there at lea≈øt ≈øo determinately ≈øet down, as to be deduced with greate≈øt clearne≈øs to the Under≈øtanding and Con≈øcience of Chri≈øtians, and di≈øtingui≈øhingly from the Service of other Subordinate Rulers appointed by Chri≈øt, that ≈øo it may be waited for, and received according to his Ordinance with Faith and Obedience.

3. Seeing Chri≈øt appoints none to an Eminency of Service, without a ≈øuitable Eminency of Abilities, as is plain in the Apo≈øtles, and Evangeli≈øts; it is therefore rea≈øonable to expect ≈øome extraordinary promi≈øes of the pre≈øence of Chri≈øt to tho≈øe Superior Mini≈øters, to a≈ø≈øi≈øt them in the Conduct of their Superiority, wherein they might, above any other Mini≈øters of the Go≈øpel, Vi≈øibly and Experimentally make ≈øome approaches to the Eminent A≈ø≈øi≈øtances the Apo≈øtles and Evangeli≈øts had in the time of their Mini≈øtry, and that they have continued, and ≈øucceeded in their High Function in the Church of Chri≈øt,
≈øo, that the Hi≈øtory of the Real, Sub≈øtantial Services of Bi≈øhops to Chri≈øtianity, hath come near to the Acts of Apo≈øtles, and as much excelled that of Common Presbyters, as the Order it ≈øelf is ≈øuppo≈øed to do: Now without the≈øe three ≈øelf evident concurrent marks of Superiority, ≈øecret invi≈øible Characters are of no ≈øignification.
Que≈øt. How then is ≈øuch a Succe≈ø≈øion of Bi≈øhops, in a Superiority over Presbyters, ≈øo uncontrolably deduced from Antiquity?

An≈øw. Be≈øides all other Coincident Accounts, there is this to be given. After the Apo≈øtles, there was but a Gradual Ce≈ø≈øation of Apo≈øtolick Men, Men of Eminent Graces and Extraordinary Gifts, though not of the Infallible Guidance of the Divine Spirit for the Revelation of the Go≈øpel, or the writing of Scripture; yet of more immediate Divine A≈ø≈øi≈øtances, in re≈øemblance of Timothy and Titus, for the Confirmation of the Churches planted by the Apo≈øtles, Supervi≈øal over them, and Care for them; and al≈øo for the further propagation of Chri≈øtianity, which being but newly ≈øet out, had not arrived many places, where it was to come, and ≈øo needed ≈øome more than ordinary A≈ø≈øi≈øtances: Even as Miracles did not immediately Cea≈øe, no more did the≈øe Per≈øonages extraordinary in their Endowments: Such as the≈øe were worthily in a Degree of Superiority over tho≈øe that had not the ≈øame miraculous Inablements, nor Knowledge as yet in Chri≈øtianity. Afterwards ≈øuch Manife≈øtations of the Divine Pre≈øence by Degrees retiring, and Chri≈øtianity having fixed it ≈øelf where it was then to go, and the Churches ≈øettled, the be≈øt accounts of the continuing Di≈øtinction between tho≈øe that were upon the ≈øame level, in regard of their Gifts and Graces were but Humane Prudence and Order, which oblige no Man's Con≈øcience beyond the valuablene≈øs of the Rea≈øons of that Prudence and Order. Except undeniable Holine≈øs, Indu≈øtry, and Improv'd Under≈øtanding recommend any Per≈øon to ≈øuch Eminency. For Eminency, and being Taller than others in tho≈øe Qualifications, will make any Per≈øon a Bi≈øhop, in the true ≈øen≈øe of one, whether ≈øo ordinated or not; and cannot make him that is a Dwarf in the≈øe, truly a Bi≈øhop; however for Orders ≈øake he may ≈øtand in the place of that Figure.

He that excels in his Knowledge of, Obedience to, Zeal for, and Authority in the Word of God, ≈øeeing that Word conveys all this kind of Power from it ≈øelf, mu≈øt needs have more of that kind of Power ≈øo conveyed than others; for the more purely this Word is under≈øtood and Preached, the more Power goes out of it, and along with tho≈øe that di≈øplay it, and ≈øo they become Pa≈øtors of a higher Character, whether of a higher Order, or not.

div.head: CAP. XI. Of every Man's Obligation to be wi≈øe for him≈øelf to Salvation.
div.p: Que≈øt. ACcording to all the precedent Accounts of the Church, it ≈øeems not only rea≈øonable, but mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary, every Man ≈øhould be wi≈øe for him≈øelf unto Salvation?

An≈øw. It is certainly ≈øo: for every Man is to be determin'd by the Word of God to the True Religion; to which purpo≈øe, he is to apply his Mind to ≈øearch for true Wi≈ødom, as for Silver, and to ≈øeek for it, as for hidden Trea≈øure.
Que≈øt. How ≈øhould Men of ≈øo great Di≈øadvantages to ≈øuch High Things be inabled to Judge?

An≈øw. Wi≈ødom a≈ø≈øumes mo≈øt ju≈øtly to it ≈øelf to be of ≈øo high Value, that every Man ≈øhould think it worth his while, to Labour, and Travel herein; and to them that do ≈øo, it hath promi≈øed the mo≈øt certain Succe≈øs, even the pouring out its Spirit to them, and that they ≈øhall under≈øtand the Fear of the Lord, and find the Knowledge of God: The Things of greate≈øt moment are not of ≈øuch difficulty, but that they are attainable in the u≈øe of Right Means, under ≈øo great Promi≈øes.
Que≈øt. What are tho≈øe Right Means?

An≈øw. Bowing down our Ears to the Words of the Wi≈øe; that is, of tho≈øe that by In≈øpiration from God have been Wi≈øe, and written their Wi≈ødom for Future Ages; and by applying our Hearts to Divine Knowledge, upon which they come to be inlay'd within us, and to be
fitted to our Lips, to be agreeable and well matched to our Di≈øcour≈øe, and not like a Parable in a Fools Mouth.
Que≈øt. But are not the≈øe things ≈øpoken, and written to the Learned and Elders of the ‚Ä¢ hurch, that they might know for the People, and the People put their tru≈øt in them?
Que≈øt. If this was the ≈øen≈øe of the Old Te≈øtament, it is undoubtedly much more ≈øo of the New?

An≈øw. It mu≈øt needs be ≈øo, as a higher, and more Intellectual State of the Church, as much freer, and clearer in its Notions of Truth: The Apo≈øtles Di≈øcour≈øe Chri≈øtians, as no Chri≈øtians, if they are not able to Judge, as Wi≈øe Men, what they ≈øay: If they are not Men in under≈øtanding, if they attain not to the ≈øtate of Teachers, by skill in the Word of Righteou≈øne≈øs, and have ≈øen≈øes exerci≈øed to di≈øcern, by an Intellectual and Spiritual Gu≈øt, Things Good and Evil; if they cannot give an Apology, or Defence of the Hope that is in them, that is, of their Chri≈øtianity, to every one that asks them a Rational Account of it.
Que≈øt. But in things of Perplexity, and Doubt, are not Chri≈øtians bound to ≈øubmit to the Judgments of their Teachers?

An≈øw. If they can receive and dige≈øt their Rea≈øon, and take in the Light they judge by, ≈øo as to make it their own; el≈øe if they cannot find their Rea≈øons, nor acquit them≈øelves from doubt, they mu≈øt ≈øu≈øpend. For a Chri≈øtian is Commanded by his Lord, to call no Man upon Earth Ma≈øter, or Father.
Que≈øt. What is the meaning of that?

An≈øw. It is this very Thing, that we ≈øhould receive nothing as Doctrine, or Indi≈øputable Truth, or Precept, upon any Man's Word, that does not offer ≈øuch Rea≈øon and Authority from God, and his Word, that we our ≈øelves ≈øee Rea≈øon, not to receive it as the Word of Man, but of God.

Que≈øt. But is it not ≈øaid, that they that have the Rule over us, watch for our Souls, as they that mu≈øt give an Account for the ≈øame? If we are not to believe them, and ≈øurrender our Judgment to theirs, how can they give an Account?

An≈øw. They that Rule over us, watch for our Souls, and mu≈øt give an Account, as Ezekiel's Prophets and Watchmen, by giving Warning, laying Truth before us, offering the ≈øincere Word of God in all Ca≈øes; the ≈øucce≈øs of which upon Souls Converted and Saved is their Crown and Glory; and their un≈øucce≈øs lookes like a ≈øorrow, to ≈øee tho≈øe Souls lo≈øt, for whom they laboured in vain, and ≈øpent their ≈øtrength upon them for nought; yet ≈øo, that if they have been faithful, though without ≈øucce≈øs, their reward is with the Lord, and their Work with God: But notwith≈øtanding this, every Man is ≈øo to account for his own Soul, that the very ≈øucce≈øs is not a Blind Obedience to Rulers, but as is ≈øaid, a Receiving the Word, not as the Word of Men, but as it is indeed the Word of God: And if the≈øe Watchmen neglect their Duty, or Seduce in≈øtead of Teaching, Men are to apply to better Means afforded by God; and if they do not, they ≈øtill die in their Iniquity, and, following their Blind Leaders, fall into the Pit; which is an unan≈øwerable Argument, that we may tru≈øt in no Man, but in God only: For if an implicit Faith could be a ≈øaving Faith, it ≈øhould ≈øave tho≈øe that followed ≈øuch Guides, though they them≈øelves were ju≈øtly Condemned in not di≈øcharging their Tru≈øt.
Que≈øt. But were not the Apo≈øtles, and Prophets, to be Tru≈øted at a higher rate than thus?

An≈øw No: There were ≈øuch evident Marks of Divine Doctrine always given by God, to tho≈øe that de≈øired to Know, Love, and Obey him, that even the very Prophets and Apo≈øtles were not to be received without them, nor to be believed but according to them, nay, to be plainly Anathematiz'd, if they varied from it: Chri≈øtians were therefore to judge, to try the Spirits, to ≈øearch the Scriptures, whether the things ≈øpoken were ≈øo; to have recour≈øe to undoubted Principles of Truth, that were as ≈øtandards to all that came after, be≈øides the Unction from the Holy One, whereby they were inabled to know all things nece≈ø≈øary to Salvation.
Que≈øt. But is not all Humane Teaching, and In≈øtruction, hereby taken away, and what becomes of the Mini≈øtry, the Elder≈øhip of the Church, and their Rule?

An≈øw. They are all hereby E≈øtabli≈øhed; for they are the Ordination of God to this very purpo≈øe, to make Men ≈øee, to bring them Light, to clear things to them, that by the awakening their Judgments, the ≈øummoning and collecting their Principles, they may ≈øee with their own Eyes the ways of God and Religion; the Holy Spirit graciou≈øly adjoyning it ≈øelf to their Mini≈øtry: They have no Dominion over their Faith, but are helpers of thier Joy; that is, they facilitate, and make plea≈øant the knowledge and a≈ø≈øurances of Religion; and they Rule, by Exhorting, Admoni≈øhing, Rebuking, Comforting, and even Commanding in the Evidences of Divine Authority, on Account of which they are to be obey'd, and highly e≈øteemed for their Works ≈øake.

Notwith≈øtanding all this, no Man is excluded from his own Office to him≈øelf; for every particular Chri≈øtian is in ≈øome Sen≈øe a Congregation, and Preacher to him≈øelf, as Solomon; his Con≈øcience hath the Keys, binds, and loo≈øes
within it ≈øelf; nay, Chri≈øtians are not excluded from Rule in the Church; when they have the Word of God on their ≈øide, they may plead and rea≈øon with their Mother, Ho≈ø. 2. 2. When they have more under≈øtanding than their Teachers, or the Rulers Rule not according to the Word of God, they that ≈øpeak according to the Law, and the Te≈øtimony, even Rule their Rulers, and prove the more noble Organs of the Church; when tho≈øe that ≈øhould Rule it, are as the Idols Eyes that ≈øee not, Ears that hear not; or as the Idol Shepherd; a Bla≈øt is upon their Right hand, and Right-eye, that their Arm is clean dried up, and their Eye utterly darkened; the mo≈øt naked unfurni≈øhed Chri≈øtian with outward Accompli≈øhments, that yet knows the Word of God, is among the Prophets in ≈øuch a time of nece≈øity.

div.head: CAP. XII. Of Schi≈øm and Scandal.
div.p: Que≈øt. FRom the precedent Di≈øcour≈øe of the Church, I conceive, the true≈øt Notion of Schi≈øm may be deduced: I de≈øire you therefore to Explain what the true Nature of Schi≈øm is?

An≈øw. The Que≈øtion concerning the Nature of Schi≈øm, follows very pertinently upon the right ≈øettlement of the Nature of the Church; now the whole Being of the Church con≈øi≈øting in its Union to God and Chri≈øt in Love, according to the Truth of his Word, and that it receives all its Members into Union with it ≈øelf, by their being fir≈øt united, as it ≈øelf is. Schi≈øm, which is Divi≈øion, mu≈øt needs, in its ≈øtricte≈øt and mo≈øt formal Notion, be a
Divi≈øion from that Truth, wherein the whole Church is one, and ≈øo from the Love con≈øequent upon ≈øuch an Union.

Wherein then Con≈øcience is mi≈øtaken, and misjudges either way, again≈øt that which is Commanded by God, or for that which is forbidden by him, there is nothing to be done, but to reduce Con≈øcience to its Right Rules, which is the Will of God in every thing, revealed in his
Word. But in things neither Commanded, nor Forbidden, if Con≈øcience be apprehen≈øive of danger any way, this is the Honour and Dignity that God hath conferred upon Con≈øcience, as his immediate Vicegerent in the Soul, and carrying his Authority, (by always pre≈øenting it in his Word, and Command,) that a Man ≈øhould ≈øu≈øpend his Action, wherein Con≈øcience is not ≈øatisfied, and at re≈øt concerning the Goodne≈øs of the Action; and this is the Honour which tho≈øe that are above, either in their Authority in the Church, or the ≈øtrength of their Under≈øtanding, Gifts, or Graces, ≈øhould be≈øtow upon tho≈øe that are below, that they ≈øhould not either by their Authority, Influence, or Example, Scandali≈øe the little ones, or the weak, that are ≈øo, either in regard of their low Station, or the weakne≈øs of their Gifts, and Graces, that is, draw them into the Sin of doing any thing, of which Con≈øcience hath a mi≈øtru≈øt of di≈øplea≈øing God in ≈øo doing, in regard, that it both weakens, and di≈øables Con≈øcience in the di≈øcharge of that Tru≈øt repo≈øed in it, for the carrying on the Soul in a Chri≈øtian Cour≈øe, its Authority being violated, and pro≈øtrated in the reverence due to it, and di≈øturbs the Peace and Comfort it ought to Mini≈øter to the Soul in that Cour≈øe: For by this ≈øort of Scandal, the Apo≈øtle Witne≈ø≈øes, the Weak Chri≈øtian falls into Sin, his Con≈øcience is defiled, is wounded, is grieved, is made weak: All the mi≈øchief of which, the value of indifferent things is not ≈øuch, as that it can an≈øwer, and make recompen≈øe for; and ≈øo to ≈øin thus again≈øt the weak, is to de≈øtroy them for whom Chri≈øt died, and therefore to ≈øin again≈øt Chri≈øt; which is the rea≈øon of tho≈øe weighty Di≈øcour≈øes of our Saviour again≈øt Scandal, Mark 18. and of the Apo≈øtle, Rom. 4. and 1 Cor. c. 8. and cap. 10. which being compared, give great light one to another.

Que≈øt. But it ≈øeems, that a Con≈øcience only in doubt, might be ≈øetled by the Advice, Example, and Authority of tho≈øe
that are the Elders, or Eminent Members of the Church; for when Doubt ≈øuppo≈øes the Con≈øcience inclining neither this way, nor that way, in it ≈øelf, but ≈øtanding between both, or ≈øometimes moving to one ≈øide, and then to the other, the coming in of tho≈øe Con≈øiderations, taken from the Example and Authority forenamed, ≈øhould give an over-weight to that ≈øide on which they fall?

An≈øw. Yet on purpo≈øe to ≈øhew the great Dignity of Con≈øcience, and its Government, without which approving, and directing accordingly, even Obedience to the Divine Commands wants the ju≈øt Complement of a Good Action; and al≈øo to ≈øhew of how little moment in Chri≈øtianity, all things are, not under a Divine Sanction, the whole weight of the Apo≈øtles Di≈øcour≈øe is hung upon a doubting Con≈øcience; a Con≈øcience in doubt concerning things indifferent, when urg'd either way.
Que≈øt. But are not all Sinnews of Government hereby cut, and di≈ø≈øolv'd, even of Civil Government; for Con≈øcience may be in relation to ≈øuch Commands di≈øatisfied?

An≈øw. As Scripture every where ≈øuppo≈øes the whole Government in the Church of God to be confined within the Monarchy and Word of Chri≈øt, and nothing to be Impo≈øed or Forbidden but according to that; ≈øo it doth every where di≈øintere≈øt the Church of Chri≈øt to judge or intermeddle in Civil Government, or Things pertaining to it; it ≈øuppo≈øes Civil Powers will oblige to, and determine Indifferencies in Civil things, this way, or that way, as they plea≈øe, and therein exerci≈øe a Lord≈øhip; but Chri≈øt having declared, it ≈øhall not be ≈øo among his Di≈øciples, does yet Command by him≈øelf, and his Apo≈øtles, all Obedience to the≈øe Principalities and Powers, even thus Commanding, if not again≈øt Gods Command directly; ≈øo that in all ≈øuch things the Doubting Con≈øcience is only to be in≈øtructed in its Rule and Duty, but can have no more Relief again≈øt Obedience to Civil Commands, than it hath again≈øt Obedience
to the Commands of God, when it is mi≈øtaken about tho≈øe Commands; for ≈øuch Obedience to Magi≈øtrates, is Obedience to the Divine Command.

Que≈øt. There appears ≈øo near an A≈ø≈øinity in the Commands concerning Indifferent Things, of tho≈øe that have Rule in the Church, with the Commands of tho≈øe that have Civil Rule, that the one may be a Mea≈øure for the other; or wherein is the difference, e≈øpecially when they joyn in one in their Commands concerning the≈øe Indifferoncies?

An≈øw. The Commands of Civil Authority concerning Indifferent Things in Religion, de≈øerves a particular con≈øideration, for which a proper place ≈øhall be re≈øerv'd. But that the Church is ≈øuch a kind of Political Regiment, that ≈øhould ≈øet up for it ≈øelf, as one of the Polities of this World, by Canons and Con≈øtitutions of its own, not founded in the Word of God, but introduced on other pretences, and that if Chri≈øtians do not Submit to them, they ≈øhould be accounted Schi≈ømaticks; and Excommunicated as Heathens, if they do not hear the Church, that is, th ‚Ä¢ Rulers of the Church, thus Ordaining in their own Wi≈ødom, and all this by the Charter of the Keys, or the Power of Binding or Loo≈øing, is as gro≈øs a Forgery, as Popery hath any in this Point: Indeed if there were ≈øuch a ≈øtate of things, there were rea≈øon to believe the whole Church ≈øhould by proper ways and means, found out by Chri≈øt, be modelled into one univer≈øal Uniformity of Government and Ceremony, ≈øeeing the whole Church is but one, and that the Romane, ≈øuppo≈øing it had not ≈øo gro≈øsly contradicted the Laws of Chri≈øt, might ≈øooner pretend to be the Metropolis of it, and the Bi≈øhop of Rome the Head of the Unity, than any other, it being the fir≈øt Imperial City that was famous for Chri≈øtianity.

But how little Uniformity is to Chri≈øt or his Kingdom, in tho≈øe things wherein he hath not interpo≈øed at all, but left Chri≈øtians free, and intended they ≈øhould be free, appears
in the Ununiform Unity of the Hi≈øtory of the Evangeli≈øts concerning his Life, Doctrine, Death, and Re≈øurection. To ≈øuppo≈øe therefore the Church to be in this manner Uniformed by the Prudence of its Governours, is to turn it ≈øo far into a Civil State, and the Bi≈øhops of it, into Lay-Elders.

div.head: CAP. XIII. Of the Anti-Church, and its Oppo≈øition in every Thing to the True Church.
div.p: Que≈øt. IS there not an Anti-Church, or Antichri≈øtian-Church, that ≈øtands in Oppo≈øition to the True-Church?
An≈øw. There is, and hath been ≈øo for many Ages, and that hath taken upon it in the mo≈øt Publick way, to be the Church of Chri≈øt, the Hou≈øe of the Living God, the Pillar and Ground of Truth.
Que≈øt. With what Advantages hath it been arm'd thus to take upon it ≈øelf at all the Name of a Church?

An≈øw. It having ri≈øen out of the True Ancient Apo≈øtolick Church, that received the True Chri≈øtianity from the Apo≈øtles at Rome, and the Faith of which, as the Apo≈øtle Paul witne≈ø≈øes, Rom. 1. 8. was ≈øpoken of throughout the World; it hath retain'd the Scriptures, and the Fundamentals of Chri≈øtianity, the Writings of the Fir≈øt Chri≈øtians and Apo≈øtolical Men, and ≈øo hath continued to do from‚ñ™ that very time of the Apo≈øtles to this Day, and hath al≈øo actuated the Truth of the Scripture, and tho≈øe Fundamentals of it, according as its Intere≈øt hath led it, in ≈øome Ages more,
in ≈øome le≈øs, as ≈øhall be pre≈øently more di≈øcovered.

Que≈øt. Having then the Scriptures, tho≈øe Fundamentals of Chri≈øtianity, and the Di≈øcour≈øes of the Ancient Fathers, and Doctors upon them, in ≈øuch a length of time, with what rea≈øon can it be looked upon as an Anti or Antichri≈øtian-Church?

An≈øw. With very great rea≈øon, becau≈øe by a multitude of Additions, fowle≈øt Idolatrous and Super≈øtitious Corruptions, and fal≈øe Interpretations upon the Scriptures, the Fundamentals of Chri≈øtianity, and the Di≈øcour≈øes of the Ancients ≈øhamefully interpolated, and by Spurious Writings under their Names de≈øpited, it hath turned whole Chri≈øtianity into a very contrary thing to it ≈øelf: while therefore it holds tho≈øe points of Chri≈øtianity, and the Records of it in veneration, and yet ≈øupports all its Fal≈øhoods thereby, it becomes perfectly an Antichurch, or Antichri≈øtian: It hath in regard of tho≈øe Articles of Truth it holds and actuates, ≈øo much, as to have the Name of a Church, and Chri≈øtian; and yet having them ≈øo fal≈øified, corrupted, and changed from them≈øelves, it becomes a Mock-Church, a Mock-Chri≈øtianity, that is, an Antichurch, and Anti-chri≈øtian, in de≈øpite of the True-Church, and True-Chri≈øtianity: And as to its Actuation of Truth, it hath ≈øo Actuated Truth, as to Actuate by Truth its own Fal≈øhoods, and Lies upon Truth.
Que≈øt. How then did it ri≈øe to ≈øuch an Eminency and pretence of being Catholick and Publick?

An≈øw. The many Concurrences of Divine Providence, under his deep and un≈øearchable Judgments in the Government of the World, in relation to that ≈øtate he had appointed for his Church, I leave to the Hi≈øtory of the Church and Roman Empire in tho≈øe times; by which may be under≈øtood, how the Papacy took the advantage to Exalt it ≈øelf, not only above the Epi≈øcopal Chairs then in an Ambitious Conte≈øt for Supremacy, but above all that was called God,
that is, the Imperial Power it ≈øelf, and ≈øo ≈øet its Foot upon the Necks of Chri≈øtian Princes throughout the World, till the great Cheat began to be detected; and all this, by and upon pretence of being the Vicar of Chri≈øt, or the Head of the Catholick, that is, the Roman-Church.

Que≈øt. The≈øe things I confe≈øs not ≈øo convenient to my Inquiry; I de≈øire only to know, how, in the middle of ≈øo many horrible Corruptions, this Antichurch could be ≈øo bold, as to vaunt it ≈øelf the ∆≤niver≈øal Church of Chri≈øt.

An≈øw. Taking the utmo≈øt benefit of its Antiquity in the Chri≈øtian-Faith, and Fundamentals of it; and e≈øpecially of the Con≈øpicuou≈øne≈øs and Famou≈øne≈øs of its State, and in the mean time the Corruptions growing up by degrees, and not ≈øo ob≈øervably as at once, (for Papal Rome was not built in a Day,) It u≈øurped the Keys of the Kingdom of Heaven as its own; the Key of Knowledge, in its Infallibility; the Keys of Power, in opening and ≈øhutting Heaven Gates, ≈øo as that in the Darkne≈øs then over≈øpreading the World, and the Church, Ignorance, the Mother of Fal≈øe-Devotion, ≈øo bewitching the Minds of Men, that they all wondered after the Roman-State, as new modelled under the Bea≈øt Arm'd with two Horns, like tho≈øe of a Lamb, counterfeiting Power from Chri≈øt the Lamb, but that ≈øpake as a Dragon, pur≈øuing all its pretendedly Chri≈øtian Decrees with the extreame≈øt Salvagene≈øs of any of the greate≈øt Earthly Tyrants, but all under a Mask of the Catholick Apo≈øtolick Church, by which Fa≈øcination of Zeal to the mo≈øt excellent Religion, though ≈øo Vitiated, Princes and People Surrendred their Power to this great Sorcere≈øs, u≈øing at once all the Frauds and Cheats of Fal≈øe-Prophe≈øie, and the Arts and Policy of the mo≈øt De≈øigning Univer≈øal Monarchy: Thus while this Antichurch ≈øtole into Power by the be≈øt appearances of True-Religion, and ≈øecured it by all the Blandi≈øhments of a Meretricious Religion; it found it ≈øelf ≈øo ≈øtrong, as to force its Fal≈øe-Religion by its
Power; and u≈øing both together, rai≈øed the Grandeur of both a Secular and Spiritual Tyranny to ≈øuch a height.
Que≈øt. But how did the True-Church in this time Actuate Truth, or agree with tho≈øe Characters of being the Hou≈øe of God, the Pillar and Ground of Truth?

An≈øw. It was by the might and prevalency of this Secular and Spiritual Tyranny ≈øo ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, that it was in a manner known only to God, who re≈øerv'd a number to him≈øelf in the mid≈øt of ≈øo great a Defection, wherein that promi≈øe was made Good, the Gates of Hell ≈øhall not prevail again≈øt his Church: Expo≈øing and Actuating Truth, pure from tho≈øe Corruptions, is hardly and very hardly to be found in Hi≈øtory, in any of the Lines and Motions of it, in the mo≈øt dark and dole≈øom period of that Defection.
