An≈øw. God rai≈øed up by extraordinary Mea≈øures of, though but an ordinary pre≈øence, ≈øuch, who by Indefatigable ≈øearches into his Truth, and Word, and tho≈øe Records of Chri≈øtianity that Antichurch was concerned to pre≈øerve, becau≈øe, as was ≈øaid, it could not without ≈øo much of a Church, be an Antichurch; and by bold Publications of it, ≈øhook ≈øo that Inchanted City, that a tenth part of it fell: And by the great contrivance of Providence, even the chief of that Antichurch were forc'd, by way of Repercu≈ø≈øion, to rai≈øe greater Light, by endeavours to defend them≈øelves, from Scripture, Antiquity and Rea≈øon, by the Summons of all, that Learning, Wit and Indu≈øtry could levy in their Defence; ≈øo that they were nece≈ø≈øitated to awaken out of that Barbarity and Ignorance in which they had been ≈øo long drown'd, and to Actuate even Truth more fiercely, that they might together with it make as potent and prevalent as they could, and give countenance to tho≈øe great Fal≈øhoods
they had interwoven with it: From all which broke out ≈øuch a light in the World, that Princes rowz'd them≈øelves, and no longer crouch'd down under ≈øuch an intoxicated Servitude, which had long gall'd and pinch'd them, but that they knew not how to rid them≈øelves from it, till the Sorcery was laid bare, which ≈øtill gave greater ≈øcope for the di≈øplay of Truth.
Que≈øt. Could the Scripture be incon≈øcious, or ≈øilent concerning ≈øo great Revolutions in the Church of God, as the≈øe?

An≈øw. It is in all True Rea≈øon mo≈øt impo≈ø≈øible; and therefore it is a mighty Argument, that tho≈øe great places of Scripture, that do ≈øo notoriou≈øly agree to ≈øuch a purpo≈øe, as the Di≈øcovery of this Antichri≈øtian State, are ju≈øtly apply'd to it by Prote≈øtant Interpreters.
Que≈øt. If you plea≈øe, point me to the chief of tho≈øe places you refer to?

An≈øw. I will do it very briefly, as being too large for the pre≈øent purpo≈øe to enumerate many, or enlarge upon any of them: But what more proper to delineate ≈øuch a State, than the Apo≈øta≈øie the Apo≈øtle de≈øcribes, 2 The≈ø≈ø. 2. 3. and 1 Timoth. 1. 4. or than the Church in the Wilderne≈øs, Revel. 12. 14. the Witne≈ø≈øes Prophecying in Sackcloth, being ≈ølain, and lying dead three Days and a half, True Chri≈øtianity being in all appearance extinct: The mea≈øuring the Altar, the Temple, and tho≈øe that Wor≈øhip in it, ≈øignifying the clo≈øe Retirement of Pure Religion, and the outward Court left to be trodden down by the Gentiles, or Heathen Chri≈øtians, and their impure Rites, and Wor≈øhip; and therefore excluded from tho≈øe ≈øtrict mea≈øures true undefiled Chri≈øtianity is enclos'd within, Revel. 11. 1 ‚Ä¢ .

Now upon all the≈øe Repre≈øentations of ≈øuch a State of the Church, ≈øo exqui≈øitely ≈øhadowed and re≈øembled, and compared with that deep plunge and immer≈øement of Chri≈øtian Religion in the time of the Popi≈øh Midnight,
who can but believe, the≈øe, with many concurrent Delineations in all tho≈øe forecited Scriptures, were on purpo≈øe to give the Portraicture of that ≈øo Fatal Apo≈øta≈øie, that believes it at all to be Prophe≈øied in the Book of God? and who, that con≈øiders the weight of the thing, can but believe it foretold, if there be any thing prophetick of the State of Chri≈øtianity to the end of the World? But if any be ≈øo incredulous, as to ≈øuppo≈øe ≈øuch a State of Chri≈øtianity beneath the Prefigurations of the Divine Spirit, he cannot, if he be indeed a Prote≈øtant, but agree, that nothing does with more Art and Divine Skill Pourtray, and Draw to the Life ≈øuch a Deva≈øtation of Chri≈øts True Religion, as all Hi≈øtory knows Popery hath made, and as far as it can prevail, does now, and would do much farther, and in its very Frame is con≈øtituted ≈øo to do.

Que≈øt. But ≈øeeing you ≈øuppo≈øe the≈øe Types of Popery may be applyed another way, though it is, I confe≈øs, very hardly to be ≈øuppo≈øed; yet I de≈øire, if any thing hath fallen under your Ob≈øervation, that can be le≈øs avoided, to make plain, how different a Religion Popi≈øh-Chri≈øtianity is from the Scripture-Chri≈øtianity, you would give me leave to ask what it is?

An≈øw. I mu≈øt needs commend your Rational Enquiry, for I know neither the Veneration given to any Religion by the Natives of it, nor the ill Words again≈øt any Religion by tho≈øe that are Strangers and Enemies to it, ≈øhould conclude again≈øt it: The Profe≈ø≈øors of every Religion are ≈øtartled at any reproach of their own Religion, as at horrible Bla≈øphemy, but freely ≈øpeak ill of a diver≈øe from it: Mahometans call them≈øelves Believers, and Chri≈øtians Infidels. Popi≈øh Religion calls it ≈øelf Catholick, and Prote≈øtancy a Grand Here≈øie, and Schi≈øm. Judai≈øm charges whole Chri≈øtianity with Cheat and Impo≈øture: It is
therefore nece≈ø≈øary, we ≈øhould have ≈øome Magnetick Needle to point us to the True Religion, and to the True Chri≈øtianity, ≈øeeing its Name is not only di≈øtributed to many, but ≈øo ≈øolemnly divided into the Popi≈øh and Prote≈øtant Profe≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øtianity.

An≈øw. I hope you have not forgotten what was at fir≈øt given in In≈øtruction concerning Natural and Revealed Religion, their exact Agreement with one another, and with all our Faculties; ≈øo that no Religion in the World can de≈øerve the Name of a Religion, but looks mon≈øtrous and horrid, only ≈øo far as it borrows ≈øome or more of the Grand Principles of our True Religion; nor can be at all Weighty and Con≈øiderable, but is vain and ridiculous, if it receive no Balla≈øt from True-Religion.

That then, which was accounted for in the beginning, being remembred, I ≈øhall e≈øpecially apply my ≈øelf to a≈øcertain True-Chri≈øtianity in contradiction to the fal≈øe, or Popi≈øh Chri≈øtianity, by that which will much a≈øcertain all True Religion al≈øo in General, and difference it from all Fal≈øe Religion.
Que≈øt. I much de≈øire to have ≈øome ≈øuch Te≈øt, as you ≈øeem to intimate and promi≈øe?

An≈øw. I cannot furni≈øh you with a better, ≈øurer, and more lively, than that Emblem of the Divine Spirit, repre≈øenting the New Jeru≈øalem by a four-≈øquare City, the Length, and the Bredth, and the Height of which are equal: The Walls, and the Gates, and the City it ≈øelf amounting to ≈øo many Square, Solid Furlongs, all exactly regulated by the Number Twelve, all of Ma≈ø≈øy-Gold and mo≈øt precious Pearl, Rev. 21.

Que≈øt. The very General view of ≈øo rich an Embleme much affects me, but I de≈øire you to lead me into the Application of it to each particular purpo≈øe, and in the fir≈øt place, what am I to under≈øtand by the City?

An≈øw. It is evidently told us, it is the New Jeru≈øalem that is coming down from Heaven, the True Church Seated in the Chri≈øtian Religion; for ≈øo the Apo≈øtle Paul a≈ø≈øures us, the Chri≈øtian Church ≈øo Spirited with True Chri≈øtianity is Jeru≈øalem, which is above, the Divine and Spiritual Jeru≈øalem, which is free, and is the Mother of us all, if True Chri≈øtians, Gal. 4. 26.

An≈øw. I am not bold, or curious in pur≈øuing Emblems too clo≈øe, but under≈øtand, in general, by the whole of all the≈øe, the Doctrine, the Wor≈øhip, the Rules of Life, the Di≈øcipline of the True Church.

An≈øw. It is very evident, the Twelve Apo≈øtles of the Lamb give the Honour to the Number Twelve; for the Prophets and Apo≈øtles, that is, the Truth mini≈øtred in≈øallibly by them, is the Foundation upon which the True Chri≈øtian Church is built, Je≈øus Chri≈øt him≈øelf being the Corner-Stone; and ≈øo to ≈øhew True Religion hath been always Sub≈øtantially the ≈øame, The Twelue Tribes of I≈ørael, and the Name of Jeru≈øalem, the People and City of God of old, are Recorded with Honour, as expre≈ø≈øive of the True Church, fixed in the True Religion in the Times before Chri≈øt.
Que≈øt. Why are all things in the Chri≈øtian State de≈øcrib'd to be of Pure Gold, and Precious Pearl?

An≈øw. To teach us by ≈øen≈øible things the tran≈øcendent Purity and Worth of Chri≈øtian Religion, and the equal Purity and Worth of all things in it, of a mo≈øt tran≈øparent clearne≈øs, being all Spiritual, Intellectual, full of Light and Truth, and ≈øo to be received and enjoy'd by Purity, and Intellectuality, or Cleare≈øt Under≈øtanding, Wi≈ødom, and Prudence in the Knowledge of this Divine Revelation,
and by greate≈øt Innocency, Cleanne≈øs and Heavenline≈øs of Heart, Affections, and Life.
Que≈øt. But can this be ≈øuppo≈øed to be the pre≈øent State of the Church of God, as it is here upon Earth?

An≈øw. This is the certain and mo≈øt unalterable Con≈øtitution and De≈øignation of God concerning it, and whoever plants it lower, in any of the Things before Named, viz. the Doctrine, Wor≈øhip, Rules of Life, or Di≈øcipline, contradicts the very thing it ≈øelf, or degrades and emba≈øes it, though it mu≈øt be acknowledged, its being thus prepared and adorned as a Bride, mu≈øt be from Heaven, in ≈øome ju≈øt ≈øea≈øon appointed by the Father: This is yet always the Tryal of the True Church, and the True Religion, although the Church be not yet perfected to it.
Que≈øt. But you ≈øeem to have forgotten the City, and all the Parts of it lying Four≈øquare, and being ≈øolid ≈øquare mea≈øure, for ≈øo it mu≈øt be, if the Length, Bredth, and Height are all equal?

An≈øw. I did not at all forget it, but ≈øuffered your Que≈øtions to lead through all, I le≈øs de≈øign'd, that they might come to the Principal Character of the True Religion and the True Church, ≈øo exactly adequate to one another.

The Subjection then is in this, as in all other Errors of Magi≈øtracy, in Ca≈øes of Ju≈øtice, or Soberne≈øs; not to re≈øi≈øt the Power, vindicating its Commands by Sufferings and Penalties upon tho≈øe that cannot actively Obey, wherein Religion, Ju≈øtice, or Soberne≈øs are contradicted, which are Gods, and mu≈øt be rendred to him according to them≈øelves, who is able to make them recompen≈øe, who ≈øuffer for Righteou≈øne≈øs ≈øake, as he plea≈øes in this World, or mo≈øt certainly in the Re≈øurrection of the Ju≈øt.

But if there were not ≈øuch an ab≈øolute Legi≈ølative and Executive Power in every Community thus fixed, and unmoveable, and accountable only to God; the Re≈øtle≈øs
Love of Change would be always di≈øturbing, and calling to account Government, and every Man take upon him to be a Lawgiver, and a Ju≈øticier, or indeed to be Licencious and Inordinate, and as they could Con≈øult and together Collect them≈øelves into a Rebellion, would enter into open Ho≈øtilities again≈øt it, and ≈øo the ends of Government in the Peace and Order of Humane Societies be quite lo≈øt; ≈øo that till any Principalities, ≈øitting on the Seats of Government, are ≈øo bad, as to retain le≈øs of the U≈øes and Ends of Government, than they de≈øtroy, and it can be made apparent, endeavours of Change cannot introduce ≈øo great and general Mi≈øchiefs, or that even Anarchy it ≈øelf cannot introduce greater Mi≈øchiefs, than that Government is the Author of, (which hath come to pa≈øs in few In≈øtances) till then, I ≈øay, we mu≈øt fear the Lord, and the King, and not meddle with them who are given to Change, For their Calamity ≈øhall ri≈øe ≈øuddenly, and who knows the ruin of them both?

Que≈øt. But what are Chri≈øtian Subjects to do, when Titles of Soveraignty, or Legi≈ølative, or Executive Powers of Laws are Di≈øputed, either betwixt various Preten≈øions of Princes, or where the bounds of Power, and Rights of Soveraignty, and the Liberties and Properties of People are in Controver≈øie?

An≈øw. I ≈øhall no more intermeddle in that, than the Doctrine of Chri≈øtianity does, which leaves all tho≈øe things to the Laws and Con≈øtitutions of Nature, of Nations, and of each Particular Country. The Duty of Chri≈øtians is to tho≈øe Soveraign Powers, who≈øe Authority is Current, who≈øe Image and Super≈øcription is upon all things Publick, the Powers that are in being, are to be Obey'd according to the Ends of Government already Di≈øcour≈øed, that is for the Puni≈øhment of Offenders; for the Executing Judgment betwixt Man and Man, for the
≈øecuring Common Peace, in all Godline≈øs and Hone≈øty: Our Lord, and his Apo≈øtles intimate nothing either way, to ≈øtrengthen or weaken the Claim of the Powers then pre≈øent; but declare Obedience to them, Prayers and Thank≈øgivings for them, as they then were, although they could not have the cleare≈øt of Titles; Chri≈øtianity as it is ≈øtrictly the Religion of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, doth not make it ≈øelf a Divider over Men, nor Decide ≈øuch Controver≈øies, which are quite of another Cogni≈øance: yet it ≈øubverts no Rights, it betrays no Liberties, ju≈øtly ≈øo called; it rever≈øes no Laws of Nature, nor re≈øcinds Con≈øtitutions, and Compacts of Government, but teaches Men to do all they can to pre≈øerve Common Good and Right determinable upon other Principles: Only this, the more clear, ancient, and indi≈øputable the Titles of Princes are, the more indi≈øputable Boundaries betwixt Prince and People are kept, the greater are the Obligations of Obedience, of quiet and peaceable re≈øt in that Obedience, of the mo≈øt vigorous Defence of the Power over us; and the greater the Guilt of any of the Sins of Mutiny, Faction, Sedition, Rebellion.
Que≈øt. The Di≈øcour≈øe of the Power of Magi≈øtrates in Religion, hath brought to my thoughts, National Religion, and a National Church, wherein I de≈øire your In≈øtruction?
An≈øw. I can but apply, what I have ≈øaid in general, to this Particular Ca≈øe, which I ≈øhall endeavour to do to your ≈øatisfaction, in the≈øe ≈øix Propo≈øitions.
Que≈øt. What is the fir≈øt Propo≈øition I am to be In≈øtructed by?

An≈øw. It is this, That to join in True Religion with our Native Country, or Nation, is ≈øuch a Law of Nature, that cannot be rever≈øed: For the ≈øake of the True Religion, we may be oblig'd to for≈øake not only our Country, but our Fathers Hou≈øe, and to unite to the
Church of God founded in that True Religion; yet in the mean time we mu≈øt own all that is Divine, Rational, True, were≈øoever we find it, much more in our Native Country, and if it be po≈ø≈øible propagate True Religion upon it: For we ≈øhall not only be judged in this World with our Nation, but ≈øhall ri≈øe with it at the Day of Judgment, in the ≈øame Station or Lott, wherein we were placed in this World; according to our doing good in it, we ≈øhall receive our Reward with tho≈øe of it, that are ≈øaved, who ≈øhall then ≈øurvive in Glory, and become, as if they were the whole Nation; the peri≈øhing part being lo≈øt; as we therefore de≈øire the pro≈øperity of it in this World, ≈øo ought we to endeavour by all means the Eternal Happine≈øs of as many of it as we can, by joyning with them, and ingaging them in True Religion.
Que≈øt. I de≈øire your Second Propo≈øition?

An≈øw. It is this, That in a Political Sen≈øe, National Religion is, when Magi≈øtrates and the Body of the People joyn in the True Religion, and E≈øtabli≈øh it by Law, and devote to it the mo≈øt Publick Advantages, that the Largene≈øs and Grandeur of ≈øuch a Nation have in their Power, fixing Characters of Civil Honour, and ample Condition upon the Rulers of the Church, and Communicating to them Magi≈øtratical Power in things pertaining to the External Defence, Honour, and Provi≈øion for the True Religion, as it is National; all which, ≈øo far as it is Serviceable to the be≈øt Ends, is acceptable to God our Saviour, who is not the Author of Confu≈øion, but of Peace; and ought to be Submitted to with Reverence, both in Obedience to Government, and al≈øo as it is done in Honour to the Name of God, and True Religion: The State of the Church in times of Per≈øecution being not the Standard (as to the≈øe things) in the pro≈øperous times of it.
Que≈øt. I now de≈øire the Third Propo≈øition?

An≈øw. The Government of a Nation in Religion, appointing and pre≈øcribing Liturgies, Confe≈ø≈øions of Faith, Catechi≈øms and Publick Forms of In≈øtruction, or Homilies, they may be ≈øo far u≈øeful, as when they are compo≈øed according to the Word of God, to ≈øecure True Religion, and the Publick Admini≈øtration of it, by ≈øo much publickly Ratified; and requiring of all, whom it Intru≈øts, as Mini≈øters of the Word of God under its Approbation and Maintenance, to a≈ø≈øent to the Truth of Religion ≈øo Compriz'd, and Publickly to declare it, by u≈øing them, as is appointed: But the≈øe are not to be under≈øtood to put Limits upon the Mini≈øters of the Word, fir≈øt entru≈øted by Chri≈øt, who are both in Prayer, Preaching the Go≈øpel, and all means of In≈øtruction, to ≈øearch into all the Scripture, that is profitable for Doctrine, In≈øtruction, Reproof, and to Pray with all Prayer and Supplication according to the particular occa≈øions, and in that abundance and liberality of the Divine Oracles, that they them≈øelves may ≈øpeak as the Oracles of God, and Pray with the ∆≤nder≈øtanding, and in the Holy Spirit, and that all their Service may be matter of Bounty from their own Minds, and not of Con≈øtraint and nece≈ø≈øity, as impos'd: For how ≈øhould they then, as every Good Scribe In≈øtructed to the Kingdom of Heaven, bring out of their Trea≈øure Things New and Old, or like the good Hou≈øholder, that hath made provi≈øion and laid up in ≈øtore to that End. In all the≈øe things Solomons Example is Great. According to which the Preacher ought to be Wi≈øe, and to teach the People Knowledge, and give good heed, and ≈øeek to find out acceptable Words, that may be as Goades and Nailes, not blunted with Common u≈øe.
Que≈øt. I now de≈øire your Fourth Propo≈øition?

An≈øw. The Benefit of National Religion E≈øtabli≈øhed by Law, is, That every Subject of that Nation, hath a Right to the True Religion ≈øo E≈øtabli≈øhed, and may claim his Intere≈øt and Property in it, as in all Things el≈øe legally due to him, and is not oblig'd upon the account of Pa≈ø≈øive Obedience, to de≈øert or relinqui≈øh his Right in it, any more than his Righteous Claim, or Title, to any thing el≈øe he enjoys by Laws, and yet Trangre≈ø≈øes no Rule of Chri≈øtianity, but hath the ≈øame Obligation to defend that his Right, as any other Right whatever, ≈øo far as the Laws of the Nation enable him, nor can there be any Re≈øi≈øtance to Government in ≈øo doing; even as there can be none, but it is the Duty and Tru≈øt of Subordinate Magi≈øtrates to adhere to the Laws in the point of True Religion, as in all other Ca≈øes; and of the Supreme Legi≈ølative Power of a Nation, to fore≈øee Dangers and prevent them by Additional Laws, as nece≈ø≈øity ≈øhall require: And all this with the Prerogative due to Religion.
Que≈øt. I de≈øire your Fifth Propo≈øition?

An≈øw. National Religion, ≈øeeing it is de≈øign'd to Comprehend a multitude of Per≈øons of mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily, and unavoidably various Sentiments and Apprehen≈øions, mu≈øt be ≈øo prepared, as that with greate≈øt Ea≈øe and Room to Con≈øciences and Under≈øtandings, of ≈øo many ≈øeveral Figures and Impre≈ø≈øions, there may be an Union in National Religion with lea≈øt Scruple, and therefore to give all the Liberty, that Truth gives, not impo≈øing Arbitrarily, becau≈øe Religion as hath been ≈øaid, is Gods Peculiar, and in that, the Doubting Con≈øcience cannot Obey farther, than it ≈øees the Divine Rule before it, not in things Dark and Di≈øputable, becau≈øe clear things are only nece≈ø≈øary to Salvation, not forcibly, except when Natural Religion is Violated, becau≈øe patient In≈øtruction, Coun≈øel, and Ratiocination are the Divine Methods in giving and working Faith.
Que≈øt. I now expect the la≈øt Propo≈øition?
An≈øw. I ≈øhall give you the la≈øt, and therein Conclude this whole Enquiry, and In≈øtruction, and it is this,

The True Religion of the Word of God in a Nation, or City, does overtop all the Fal≈øe and Private Religions in it, and become in the Sacred Regi≈øter, the National Religion. In the Sacred Maps, the Chri≈øtians of Achaia, were Achaia it ≈øelf: The Seven Churches of A≈øia, were the Cities them≈øelves: And whatever Le≈ø≈øer Differences, or Divi≈øions, this or that Name of Di≈øtinction may ≈øeem to make in National Religion, yet, the True Sub≈øtantial Religion in all of them ≈øhall be one National Religion; and become one Rod and Scepter in the Hand of Chri≈øt, and the Nation be as one National Tribe, and Church: For let Men do what they can again≈øt it, True Religion, as it is the only Publick Religion, and no Separation of Men from it, however called Publick, can make it Private; ≈øo in what place ≈øoever it is, it ≈øhall have the mo≈øt Publick Character, and the True Religion in all tho≈øe that ≈øincerely profe≈øs it, ≈øhall be one True Publick Religion, and tho≈øe little Differences ≈øhall not cleave it into more than one. Without the Change of True Religion it ≈øelf, there cannot be a Schi≈øm of a deeper Sen≈øe in it; if Bitterne≈øs and Animo≈øity, Cen≈øoriou≈øne≈øs, and the Per≈øecuting Spirit were away: God will graciou≈øly Interpret Scruples on one ≈øide to a Jealou≈øie for the Purity of Religion, the freedom of the other to a de≈øire to Propagate it under the favour of Laws, and thereby to be capable of doing mo≈øt Good. In Heaven they now are all one, and ≈øhall be one, and the Envy, Strife, and Contention (which the Good Lord Pardon) ≈øhall be utterly Aboli≈øhed. This is the Honour of True Religion, of Publick Divine Religion.

Now the God of Peace, that brought again from the Dead, our Lord Je≈øus, that great Shepherd of the Sheep, by the Blood of the everla≈øting Covenant, make his Church, and his Church in this Nation, perfect in every Good Work, to do his Will, Working in it, that which is well plea≈øing in his ≈øight, through Je≈øus Chri≈øt, to whom be Glory for ever and ever, Amen.
